case_data.name: Lopez v. Youngblood
case_data.plaintiff_description: Plaintiffs represent a class of persons who were forced to undergo unlawful strip and/or visual body cavity searches in Kern Countyโs jails which are operated, maintained and under the control of the County and the Kern County Sheriff's Department.
settlement_agreement: Court Approved Settlement or Consent Decree
case_data.summary:
On March 27, 2007, Plaintiffs, individually and as class representatives, filed a civil rights action under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California, Fresno Division, against Kern County California, the Kern County Sheriff's Department ("KCSD"), and officials in their supervising capacity. Plaintiffs seek injunctive relief and damages resulting from the strip and/or visual body cavity searches of prisoners by Defendants.

The complaint, later amended, pursues causes of action for violations of the Fourth, Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments to the U.S. Constitution, violation of Article I, ยงยง 1, 7, 13 and 17 of the California Constitution and state law violations. Plaintiffs allege that Defendants maintained a policy of indiscriminately strip/body cavity searching all or a large number of persons being processed into the jail without limitation on the number of persons who can see, hear or observe the searches. Plaintiffs also allege that Defendants improperly strip searched detainees who had been ordered released.

On July 17, 2008, Defendants filed a joint motion for summary adjudication regarding liability of entities and individuals as to group strip searches. Defendants contend that the group strip searches at issue do not violate the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments. In addition, Defendants argue that Plaintiffs' equal protection claim and state law claims fail as a matter of law.

On June 17, 2008, Plaintiffs filed a motion for class certification, seeking certification of two classes--the Post-Release Class and the Group Strip Search Class.

On November 7, 2008, Defendants filed a second joint motion for summary adjudication regarding court returnees, qualified immunity and Eleventh Amendment immunity. Defendants contend that (1) the searches of certain Plaintiffs who assert that their constitutional rights were violated when they were subjected to strip searches after returning to the jail following a court appearance in which they were ordered released were reasonable; (2) Defendants are immune from liability because the law was not clearly established that searching post-arraignment detainees in small groups violates Plaintiffs' rights under the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments and violates the Equal Protection Clause; (3) the Sheriff is a state actor and immune from a ยง 1983 suit; and (4) the County should be dismissed from the action.

On November 7, 2008, Plaintiffs filed a cross-motion for partial summary judgment and/or summary adjudication. Plaintiffs sought a determination that (1) KCSD's policy of strip searching persons ordered released from custody violated the Fourth Amendment; (2) KCSD's policy of group strip searching prisoners violated the Fourth Amendment; (3) the strip search policies violated Plaintiffs' state constitutional rights pursuant to Cal. Const. Art. I, ยง 1 (privacy), Cal. Const. Art. I, ยง 13 (unreasonable searches) and Cal. Const. Art. I, ยง 7 (equal protection); and (4) the entity defendants are liable under federal and state law.

On March 31, 2009, in a published order, the Court (Magistrate Judge Dennis L. Beck) granted in part and denied in part the parties' motions for partial summary judgment/summary adjudication and on April 01, 2009, certified the two putative Plaintiff classes.

Plaintiffs and Defendants sought interlocutory appeals to the Ninth Circuit. However, pursuant to the stipulation of the parties and the supplemental letter filed by counsel on January 21, 2011, these consolidated appeals were voluntarily dismissed without prejudice. On January 21, 2011, the parties filed a joint motion for preliminary approval of a class settlement in the District Court.

On February 23, 2011, the District Court preliminarily approved the Settlement Agreement. In a nutshell, the Settlement Agreement provides that: (1) each Post-Release Class Member who files a claim shall receive $1500; (2) each Group Strip Search Class Member shall receive $200; (3) Post-Release Class Members may receive an additional $750 if s/he was subjected to a second such search during the class period; (4) the class payment figures are subject to certain aggregate maximums to be paid each class (totaling approximately $4,350,000 for the two classes combined), after which payments would be prorated; (5) Defendants shall separately pay $30,000 to each of the three named plaintiffs, pay the cost of class administration, pay class counsel costs not to exceed $65,000, and pay class counsel attorneys' fees of $2 million.

On August 31, 2011, the District Court issued a final order to approve the Settlement. On September 02, 2011, the District Court awarded the class counsels attorneys' fees in the amount of $2 million, and costs in the amount of $44,393.60.

(Updated on April 21, 2012)

1 I.  INTRODUCTION 
2 1.  This action concerns the manner in which prisoners are searched in Kern  
3 Countyโs jails, alleging, inter alia, violations of the Fourth, Eighth and Fourteenth 
4
Amendments of the United States Constitution, and their corollaries under the 
5
California Constitution.   
6
2.   The gravamen of this complaint concerns the privacy rights of prisoners 
7
who are routinely subjected to strip and/or visual body cavity searches in violation 
8
of the constitutions and laws of the United States and the State of California. 
9
II.   JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
10
3.   Plaintiffs present federal claims for relief under 42 U.S.C. ยง1983. 
11
Accordingly, federal jurisdiction is conferred upon this Court by 28 U.S.C.          
12
ยงยง1331 and 1343.  Plaintiffsโ state law claims are so related to the federal law 
13
claims that they form part of the same case or controversy.  Accordingly, 
14

15
28 U.S.C. ยง1367. 
16
4.   Plaintiffsโ claims arise out of acts of the Kern County Sheriffโs Department 
17
in the County of Kern, State of California, in and about Bakersfield, California.  
18

19

21

22
23 resident of the County of Kern, State of California.

25 resident of the County of Kern, State of California.

27 resident of the County of Kern, State of California. 
28  
  2

1   Defendants 
2 8.  Defendant County of Kern (โCountyโ) is a public entity organized and 
3 existing under the laws of the State of California.  Defendant Kern County 
4
Sheriffโs Department (โKCSDโ) is a public entity within the meaning of California 
5

6

7

ยง815.2 and mandatory duties under California Government Code ยง815.6.

11

14

22
23 of.

25 defendantsโ) were and are now responsible for the KCSD jails and, among other 
26 things, are responsible for the training, supervision, control, assignment and 
27 discipline of the sworn and civilian personnel of the KCSD and County who work 
28 in, operate, administer and manage the jails, and for the formulation, promulgation, 
  3

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 10    Filed 06/21/07   Page 4 of 17
   
1 adoption, application, administration and enforcement of the policies, rules, 
2 regulations and practices of the KCSD jails. 
3 13.  Upon information and belief, plaintiffs further allege that, at all times 
4
relevant herein, the KCSD Supervisory defendants participated in, approved, 
5
and/or ratified the unconstitutional or illegal acts complained of herein that 
6
occurred within KCSD jails.  
7
14.  DOES 51-100 were and are now KCSD employees and/or agents 
8
responsible for the implementation of the policies, rules, regulations and practices 
9
of the KCSD jails, and include KCSD employees who actually implemented and 
10
enforced the unlawful policies and practices complained of herein. 
11
15.  Plaintiffs are informed and believe, and thereupon allege that, at all times 
12
relevant herein, the individual defendants, and each of them, were the agents, 
13
servants and employees of their respective employers (defendants KCSD, County) 
14
and were acting at all times within the scope of their agency and employment, and 
15
with the knowledge and consent of their principals and employers. At all times 
16
herein, defendants, and each of them, were acting under the color of state law. 
17
IV.   CLAIMS OF CLASS REPRESENTATIVES 
18
  Plaintiff Marsial Lopez 
19
16.  On or about late June 2005, plaintiff Lopez surrendered himself to out-of-
20
state law enforcement officers upon learning that there was a Kern County felony 
21
warrant for his arrest for charges filed in the Kern County Superior Court. 
22
23 Thereafter, Lopez was incarcerated in the Kern County jails, commencing late June 
24 2005 and continuing until the first week of November, 2006. 
25 17.  During his incarceration in the Kern County jails, KCSD deputies 
26 transported Lopez to and from the Kern County Superior Court for appearances on 
27 plaintiffsโ then pending criminal case. Whenever Lopez was transported between 
28 jail facilities, and when he was returned to jail from superior court, he was 
  4

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 10    Filed 06/21/07   Page 5 of 17
   
1 subjected to intrusive visual body cavity/strip searches. That is, in the presence of 
2 others not necessary for the searches and without any privacy, Lopez was forced to 
3 remove all of his clothing, expose his body cavities in the presence of other 
4
persons, in unsanitary conditions. 
5
18.  On or about November 6, 2006, Lopez, still incarcerated in the Kern County 
6
jail and awaiting a retrial (in his first trial the jury deadlocked 11-1, in favor of 
7
acquittal) was taken before the Kern County Superior Court. At that time the 
8
prosecuting authority dismissed all criminal charges against him. The prosecutor 
9
dismissed the charges because the prosecutorโs office finally decided to test DNA 
10
found on clothing recovered from the crime scene. The DNA test results excluded 
11
him as the perpetrator of the charged crimes. 
12
19.  After the charges were dismissed, the superior court ordered Lopezโ release. 
13
At that point KCSD deputies returned Lopez to the Kern County jail for the sole 
14
purpose of processing his release from custody. Upon arrival at the jail, Lopez was 
15
subjected to an illegal and intrusive visual body cavity/strip search, in unsanitary 
16
conditions, without privacy, and without reasonable suspicion that he possessed 
17
contraband or weapon(s). The search took place in the presence of persons not 
18
necessary for the search, forcing Lopez to expose his body cavities in the presence 
19
of other persons, without privacy, and in unsanitary conditions. 
20
20.  Lopez has timely filed a claim under Government Code ยง910 with the 
21
County of Kern, both on behalf of himself and other persons similarly situated. 
22
23   Plaintiff Sandra Chavez 
24 21.  On or about February 17, 2007, plaintiff Chavez was arrested by KCSD 
25 personnel, placed in KCSD custody after arrest, and transported to a Kern County 
26 jail facility.  Chavez was arrested on a charge related to fighting in public. 
27 22.  Upon her arrival at the jail, KCSD personnel subjected Chavez to an 
28 intrusive strip and visual body cavity search.  During the search KCSD employees 
  5

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 10    Filed 06/21/07   Page 6 of 17
   
1 required Chavez to remove all of her clothing, and to bend and squat, exposing her 
2 anus and vagina.  Chavez was searched in a room along with approximately four or 
3 five other women. At the time of the search, KCSD personnel did not have 
4
probable cause or reasonable suspicion that Chavez or the other prisoners were in 
5
the possession of contraband, or any other substance that would justify or 
6
necessitate the strip and/or body cavity search.  A male officer, though not 
7
participating in the strip search, was within view of Chavez during the search. 
8
23.  After being booked and strip searched, Chavez was given a court date and 
9
released from custody.  She was not arraigned until two weeks later, where she was 
10
sentenced to probation and a fine. 
11
24.  Chavez has timely filed a claim under Government Code ยง910 with the 
12
County of Kern, both on behalf of herself and other persons similarly situated. 
13
  Plaintiff Theodore Medina 
14
25.  On or about June 7, 2006, plaintiff Medina was arrested by KCSD 
15
personnel, placed in KCSD custody after arrest, and transported to a Kern County 
16
jail facility.  Medina was arrested on a charge of public intoxication. 
17
26.  Upon arrival at the jail, KCSD personnel subjected Medina to an intrusive 
18
strip and visual body cavity search.  During the search KCSD employees required 
19
Medina to remove all of his clothing, and to bend and squat, exposing his anus.  
20
Medina was searched in a room along with approximately four or five other 
21
arrestees. At the time of the search, KCSD personnel did not have probable cause 
22
23 or reasonable suspicion that Medina or the other arrestees were in the possession of 
24 contraband, or any other substance that would justify or necessitate the strip and/or 
25 body cavity search.  The strip and visual body cavity search described herein 
26 occurred before Medina was arraigned. 
27 27.  Within two years from the filing of this complaint, Medina was also arrested 
28 on a charge of spousal abuse, placed in KCSD custody after arrest, and transported 
  6

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 10    Filed 06/21/07   Page 7 of 17
   
1 to a Kern County jail facility.  While being booked KCSD personnel subjected 
2 Medina to an intrusive strip and visual body cavity search, in the presence of others 
3 not involved in his search, and in unsanitary conditions.  After spending 17 days in 
4
a Kern County jail facility, Medina appeared in court, was sentenced to time served 
5
and ordered released by the judge.  After the order of release, Medina was 
6
transferred from court to jail and, as a routine part of out-processing, was subjected 
7
to an intrusive strip search, in the presence of others not involved in his search, and 
8
in unsanitary conditions.  At the time of the aforementioned searches, KCSD 
9
personnel did not have probable cause or reasonable suspicion that Medina was in 
10
possession of contraband, or any other substance that would justify or necessitate 
11
the strip and/or visual body cavity search. 
12
V.   CLASS ACTION ALLEGATIONS 
13
28.  Plaintiffs bring this action on their own behalf, and on behalf of a class of all 
14
other persons similarly situated, pursuant to Rule 23 of the Federal Rules of Civil 
15
Procedure. The class is defined as those persons who, in the two years preceding 
16
the filing of this action, and up until the date of class certification, or such other 
17
date as the Court may set, were forced to undergo unlawful strip and/or visual body 
18
cavity searches in Kern Countyโs jails which are operated, maintained and under 
19
the control of the County, the KCSD and the Supervisory defendants. 
20
29.  On information and belief, plaintiffs allege the strip and/or visual body 
21
cavity searches to which they and class members were subjected, were done 
22
23 pursuant to defendantsโ policy and practice to indiscriminately search all or a large 
24 number of persons being processed into the jail without regard to: a) The nature of 
25 their offense or criminal history; b) Whether they are under an order of release or 
26 not; c) Whether they have had contact with any persons from outside the County 
27 jail system who could reasonably be believed to be a potential source of 
28 contraband or weapons; d) Whether there is cause of any kind to believe they are a 
  7

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 10    Filed 06/21/07   Page 8 of 17
   
1 potential source of contraband or weapons; e) Whether there is any other 
2 articulable justification for defendantsโ indiscriminate strip and body search policy; 
3 or f) Whether they are โprearraignment detainees,โ as that term is used in 
4
California Penal Code ยง4030(b). 
5
30.  On information and belief, plaintiffs allege that defendants have a policy of 
6
not limiting the persons who can see or hear or observe all or part of the strip and 
7
body cavity searches to those who are necessary to the procedure. Thus, other 
8
inmates, members of the opposite six, dispensable jail personnel and possibly 
9
others are able to see and/or hear some or all of the searches described below.  
10
Specifically, class members are required to submit to strip and/or body cavity 
11
searches during which other people, who are not participating in the search and 
12
possibly are of the opposite sex, including jail staff and other inmates, are able to 
13
observe the search and the class membersโ naked bodies.  In many instances, class 
14
members are forced to touch each otherโs bodies during the searches. 
15
31.  On information and belief, plaintiffs allege that defendants will continue 
16
their aforementioned policy and practice of unlawful strip and/or visual body 
17
cavity searches unless enjoined and restrained by the court.  Without injunctive 
18
relief applicable to the class as a whole, the class members will suffer irreparable 
19
harm for which there is no adequate remedy at law in that their constitutional and 
20
statutory rights will be systematically violated. 
21
VI.   RULE 23 PREREQUISITES 
22
23   A.  Numerosity 
24 32.  In accordance with F.R.Civ. P. Rule 23(a), the members of the class are so 
25 numerous that joinder of all members is impracticable. Plaintiffs do not know the 
26 exact number of class members. Plaintiffs are informed and believe and thereon 
27 allege that there are more than 50 prisoners per day who are subjected to strip 
28 and/or body cavity searches as a result of defendantsโ policies and practices of 
  8

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 10    Filed 06/21/07   Page 9 of 17
   
1 indiscriminately subjecting prisoners to strip and body cavity searches. Plaintiffs 
2 are informed and believe and thereon allege that the number of persons in the 
3 proposed class is in the thousands. 
4
  B.  Common Issues of Fact or Law 
5
33.  In accordance with F.R. Civ. P. Rule 23(a), there are questions of fact 
6
common to the class. Plaintiffs are informed and believe and thereon allege that the 
7
common questions of fact include, but are not limited to the following: (1) 
8
Whether the KCSD routinely subjects all prisoners to strip and/or body cavity 
9
searches without there being any reasonable suspicion, based on specific or 
10
articulable facts, to believe any particular inmate has concealed drug(s), weapon(s) 
11
and/or any contraband on their persons or in their body cavities; (2) Whether the 
12
strip and/or body cavity searches are conducted in an area of privacy so that the 
13
search cannot be observed by persons not participating in the search, or whether 
14
the strip and body cavity searches are conducted in areas where they may be 
15
observed by persons not participating in the searches; and (3) Whether the strip 
16
and/or body cavity searches are conducted in an unsanitary area, infested with 
17
bacteria such as MRSA and other communicable diseases. 
18
34.  In accordance with F.R. Civ. P. Rule 23(a), there are questions of law 
19
common to the class.  Plaintiffs are informed and believe and thereon allege that 
20
the common questions of law include but are not limited to the following: (1) 
21
Whether the KCSD may indiscriminately conduct strip and/or body cavity searches 
22
23 of inmates without there being any reasonable suspicion, based on specific or 
24 articulable facts, to believe any particular inmate has concealed drug(s), weapon(s) 
25 and/or any contraband on their persons or in their body cavities; (2) Whether the 
26 KCSD may conduct strip and/or body cavity searches of inmates in open areas 
27 where they may be observed by persons not participating in the searches; (3) 
28 Whether KCSDโs policy of subjecting persons to strip and/or body cavity searches 
  9

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 10    Filed 06/21/07   Page 10 of 17
   
1 violates California Penal Code ยง4030; (4) Whether KCSDโs policy of subjecting 
2 persons to strip and/or body cavity searches in an area which is not an โarea of 
3 privacyโ violates California Penal Code ยง4030(m); (5) Whether the conduct 
4
described above violates the Fourth and/or Fourteenth Amendments, and/or 
5
California Constitution Article I, ยงยง1, 7, and/or 13; (6) Whether the conduct 
6
described above constitutes a policy or custom of the defendants; (7) Whether any 
7
individual defendant is entitled to qualified immunity on the federal claims, or state 
8
law immunity on the state law claims, for the practices complained of herein; and 
9
(8) Whether determination of damages suffered by a statistically representative 
10
sample of the class provides the basis for determination of all class membersโ 
11
damages except those who opt out. 
12
  C.  Typicality 
13
35.  In accordance with F.R. Civ. P. Rule 23(a), the claims of the representative 
14
Plaintiffs are typical of the class. Plaintiffs were in KCSD custody when he was 
15
subjected to at least one strip and/or visual body cavity searches without there 
16
being any reasonable suspicion, based on specific or articulable facts, to believe 
17
that plaintiffs and class members had concealed drug(s), weapon(s) and/or any 
18
contraband in their body cavities; plaintiffs were subjected to searches in open 
19
areas where they were observed by other prisoners and persons not involved in the 
20
search, possibly including sometimes members of the opposite sex; plaintiffs were 
21
searched and forced to stand naked in unsanitary and bacteria infested areas. 
22
23 36.  Thus, plaintiffs have the same interests and have suffered the same type of 
24 damages as the class members. Plaintiffsโ claims are based upon the same or 
25 similar legal theories as the claims of the class members. Each class member 
26 suffered actual damages as a result of being subjected to a strip and/or body cavity 
27 search. The actual damages suffered by plaintiffs are similar in type and amount to 
28 the actual damages suffered by each class member. 
  10

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 10    Filed 06/21/07   Page 11 of 17
   
1 37.  In accordance with F.R. Civ. P. Rule 23(a), the representative plaintiffs will 
2 fairly and adequately protect the interests of the class. The interests of the 
3 representative plaintiffs are consistent with and not antagonistic to the interests of 
4
the class. 
5
   D.  Maintenance and Superiority 
6
38.  In accordance with Fed.R.Civ.P. Rule 23(b)(1)(A), prosecutions of separate 
7
actions by individual members of the class would create a risk that inconsistent or 
8
varying adjudications with respect to individual members of the class would 
9
establish incompatible standards of conduct for the parties opposing the class. 
10
39.  In accordance with Fed.R.Civ.P. Rule 23(b)(1)(B), prosecutions of separate 
11
actions by individual members of the class would create a risk of adjudications 
12
with respect to individual members of the class which would, as a practical matter, 
13
substantially impair or impede the interests of the other members of the class to 
14
protect their interests. 
15
40.  In accordance with Fed.R.Civ.P. Rule 23(b)(2), plaintiffs are informed and 
16
believe and thereon allege that the defendants have acted on grounds generally 
17
applicable to the class. 
18
41.  In accordance with Fed.R.Civ.P. Rule 23(b)(3), the questions of law or fact 
19
common to the members of the class predominate over any questions affecting 
20
only individual members, and this class action is superior to other available 
21
methods for the fair and efficient adjudication of the controversy between the 
22
23 parties.  Plaintiffs are informed and believe and thereon allege that the interest of 
24 class members in individually controlling the prosecution of a separate action is 
25 low, in that most class members would be unable to individually prosecute any 
26 action at all.  Plaintiffs are informed and believe and thereon allege that the 
27 amounts at stake for individuals are such that separate suits would be impracticable 
28 in that most members of the class will not be able to find counsel to represent 
  11

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 10    Filed 06/21/07   Page 12 of 17
   
1 them. Plaintiffs are informed and believe and thereon allege that it is desirable to 
2 concentrate all litigation in one forum because all of the claims arise in the same 
3 location, i.e., the County of Kern, and it will promote judicial efficiency to resolve 
4
the common questions of law and fact in one forum, rather than in multiple courts. 
5
42.  Plaintiffs do not know the identities of the class members. Plaintiffs are 
6
informed and believe and thereon allege that the identities of the class members are 
7
ascertainable from KCSD records, in particular the KCSD computer system used 
8
to track and identify KCSD inmates. Plaintiffs are informed and believe and 
9
thereon allege that the computer system reflects the identities, including addresses 
10
and telephone numbers, of the persons who have been held in custody by KCSD; 
11
when inmates were arrested and booked, taken to court, returned from court; why 
12
inmates were released; and when inmates were released.  
13
43.  Plaintiffs know of no difficulty that will be encountered in the management 
14
of this litigation that would preclude its maintenance as a class action.  The class 
15
action is superior to any other available means to resolve the issues raised on 
16
behalf of the class.  The class action will be manageable because so many different 
17
records systems exist from which to ascertain the members of the class. Liability 
18
can be determined on a class-wide basis. Damages can be determined on a class-
19
wide basis using a damages matrix set by a jury, or by trying the damages of a 
20
statistically valid sample of the class to a jury and extrapolating those damages to 
21
the class as a whole. 
22
23 44.  In accordance with Fed.R.Civ.P. Rule 23(b)(3), class members must be 
24 furnished with the best notice practicable under the circumstances, including 
25 individual notice to all members who can be identified through reasonable effort.  
26 Plaintiffs are informed and believe that KCSD computer records contain a last 
27 known address for class members.  Plaintiffs contemplate that individual notice be 
28 given to class members at such last known address by first class mail. Plaintiffs 
  12

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 10    Filed 06/21/07   Page 13 of 17
   
1 contemplate that the notice inform class members of the following: 
2 a.  The pendency of the class action, and the issues common to the class; 
3 b.  The nature of the action; 
4
c.  Their right to โopt outโ of the action within a given time, in which 
event they will not be bound by a decision rendered in the class 
5
action; 
6
 
7 d.  Their right, if they do not โopt out,โ to be represented by their own 
counsel and enter an appearance in the case; otherwise, they will be 
8
represented by the named plaintiffs and his counsel; and 
9  
e.  Their right, if they do not โopt out,โ to share in any recovery in favor 
10
of the class, and conversely to be bound by any judgment on the 
11 common issues, adverse to the class. 
 
12
45.  Plaintiffs restate and incorporate by reference each of the foregoing 
13
paragraphs in each of the following causes of action as if each paragraph was fully 
14
set forth therein. 
15
  COUNT ONE - 42 U.S.C. ยง1983 
16
  (All Defendants) 
17
46.  In subjecting plaintiffs and class members to the unnecessary, demeaning, 
18
outrageous and intrusive strip and/or body cavity searches, defendants, and each of 
19
them, violated plaintiffsโ and class membersโ rights to be secure in their persons 
20
against unreasonable searches and seizures as guaranteed by the Fourth and 
21
Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution. Therefore, plaintiffs 
22
23 and class members are entitled to bring suit and recover damages pursuant to 42 
24 U.S.C. ยง1983. 
25   COUNT TWO - EQUAL PROTECTION 
26   (All Defendants) 
27 47.  The unnecessary, demeaning, outrageous and intrusive strip and/or body 
28 cavity searches deprived plaintiffs and class members of the protections afforded 
  13

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 10    Filed 06/21/07   Page 14 of 17
   
1 by provisions of the 14th Amendment Equal Protection guarantees. Therefore, 
2 plaintiffs and class members are entitled to bring suit and recover damages 
3 pursuant to 42 U.S.C. ยง1983. 
4
  COUNT THREE - Cal. Const., Art. I ยงยง7, 13 
5
  (All Defendants) 
6
48.  The unnecessary, demeaning, outrageous and intrusive strip and/or body 
7
cavity searches to which plaintiffs and class members were subjected violated 
8
plaintiffsโ rights not to be denied equal protection of the law, as guaranteed by 
9
Article I, ยง 7 of the California Constitution; and to be secure in their persons 
10
against unreasonable searches and seizures, as guaranteed by Article I, ยง 13 of the 
11
California Constitution. 
12
  COUNT FOUR - Cal. Civ. Code ยง52.1 
13
  (All Defendants) 
14
49.  The unnecessary, demeaning, outrageous and intrusive strip and/or visual 
15
body cavity searches were accomplished via threats, intimidation and/or coercion. 
16
50.  The unnecessary, demeaning, outrageous and intrusive strip and/or visual 
17
body cavity searches deprived plaintiffs and the class they represent of the 
18
protections afforded by provisions of federal constitutional and state constitutional 
19
and statutory law, including but not limited to rights protected under the Fourth, 
20
Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution; Article I,   
21
ยงยง1, 7, 13, and 17, of the California state constitution, and California Penal Code  
22
23 ยง4030.  Therefore, plaintiffs and the class are entitled to bring suit and recover 
24 damages pursuant to Cal. Civ. Code ยง52.1(b). 
25 51.  As a direct and proximate cause of the aforementioned acts, plaintiffs and 
26 class members were damaged in an amount to be proven at trial but in any event 
27 not less than $4,000 per violation pursuant to the provisions of Civil Code ยง52(b). 
28
  14

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 10    Filed 06/21/07   Page 15 of 17
   
1 52.  The aforementioned acts of defendants directly and proximately caused 
2 plaintiffs to be deprived of their California constitutional rights as stated above, 
3 thereby entitling plaintiffs and class members to recover damages proximately 
4
caused by defendantsโ wrongful acts. 
5
  COUNT FIVE - Violation of Statutory Duties, Penal Code ยง4030 
6
  (Against All Defendants) 
7
53.  The unnecessary, demeaning, outrageous, and intrusive strip and/or body 
8
cavity searches to which plaintiffs and the class members were subjected by 
9
defendants, violated plaintiffsโ and the class membersโ state-law protections 
10
guaranteed by California Penal Code ยง4030 and equal protection guarantees. 
11
54.  Although by its terms Penal Code ยง4030 only applies to misdemeanor 
12
arrests, there is no reason to establish different standards for how a strip is 
13
conducted in order to maintain the arresteeโs privacy while allowing the strip 
14
search based on whether arrestee is charged with a misdemeanor or a felony. 
15
Accordingly, equal protection and due process of law under the Federal and 
16
California Constitutions require that the manner of strip search protections 
17
contained in Penal Code ยง4030 apply to felony arrestees as well as misdemeanor 
18
arrestees. 
19
55.  Any violation of a California statute is mandatory and prohibitory. 
20
56.  The aforementioned acts of defendants directly and proximately caused the 
21
plaintiffs and the class members to be deprived of their rights as stated above, 
22
23 thereby entitling plaintiffs and class members to recover damages proximately 
24 caused by defendantsโ wrongful acts, including statutory damages under Penal 
25 Code ยง 4030. 
26   COUNT SIX- Violation of Mandatory Duties 
27   (Against All Defendants) 
28 57.  The Fourth, Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States 
  15

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 10    Filed 06/21/07   Page 16 of 17
   
1 Constitution; Article I, ยงยง1, 7, 13, and 17, of the California state constitution; 
2 California Penal Code ยง4030; and California Civil Code ยง52.1 are enactments.  
3 Enactments form the basis of a mandatory duty under California Government Code 
4
ยง815.6. 
5
58.  These constitutional provisions and statutes apply to all members of the 
6
general public, including plaintiffs, and were all designed to prevent the kind of 
7
injuries alleged herein. 
8
59.  Defendants did not exercise reasonable diligence in discharging their duty to 
9
refrain from violating the constitutional rights of plaintiffs and class members. 
10
60.  As a direct and proximate cause of the aforementioned acts of defendants, 
11
plaintiffs and class members were damaged in amounts to be determined at trial. 
12
VII.   PRAYER 
13
  WHEREFORE, plaintiffs, on behalf of themselves and the class members 
14
they represent, request the following against each defendant as follows: 
15
61.  General and special damages according to proof; 
16
62.  Temporary, preliminary and permanent injunctive relief prohibiting 
17
defendants from continuing to engage in the unlawful practices complained 
18
of herein; 
19
63.  As against the individual defendants only, punitive damages according to 
20
proof; 
21
64.   In addition to actual damages, statutory damages as allowed by law, 
22
23 including Penal Code ยง4030 and Civil Code ยงยง52 and 52.1; 
24  
25  
26  
27  
28  
  16

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 10    Filed 06/21/07   Page 17 of 17
   
1 65.  Attorneysโ fees and costs under 42 U.S.C. ยง1988; California Civil Code     
2 ยงยง52(b)(3), 52.1(h); California Code of Civil Procedure ยง1021.5, and 
3 whatever other statute or law may be applicable; 
4
66.  The costs of this suit and such other relief as is just and proper. 
5
 
6

I.  RELIEF  REQUESTED. 
Plaintiffs,  former  prisoners  held  at  the  Kern  County  Jail  (โKCJโโ)  and  the putative 
classes  they  represent,  bring  this  facial  challenge  to  certain  Kern  County  Sheriffโs 
Departmentโs  (โโKCSDโ)  strip/visual  body  cavity  search policies  and practices.  Plaintiffs 
contend  that  the  KCSDโs  former  policies  of  (1)  routinely  strip  searchingโ  prisoners 
ordered  released  from custody  pursuant  to  court  order without  reasonable  suspicion  that 
the prisoner posses  weapons or contraband,  and  (2)  routinely  searching all prisoners  upon 
their  arrival  at  the  Lerdo  jail  in  groups,  without  privacy  and  where  the  strip  search  was 
viewed by other inmates and jail personnel not necessary to the  search, violated plaintiffsโ 
rights  under  the  federal and  state  constitutions.  Thus,  plaintiffs  contend, they  are  entitled 
to  this  Courtโs  ruling  that  defendants  are  liable  as  a matter of law  for  violating  plaintiffsโ 
rights.

I.  STATEMENT  OF  FACTS. 
14 
A.  The  Kern  County  Jail. 
15      
The  KCSD  operates  the  Kern  County  Jail  (KCJ).  The  KCJ  consists  of  Central

17

18 
at  CRF.  If  not  released  from  CRF,  arrestees  are  then  housed  at  the  Lerdo  jail.  (The 
19 
Mojave  and  Ridgecrest  jails  are  used  to  hold,  pre-arraignment,  those  arrestees  who, 
20 
21  because  of geographical  distance,  must  be  held  in  custody  while  awaiting  transport  to 
22  CRF in  Bakersfield.) Plaintiffsโ Statement of Undisputed Facts  (hereinafter โPSUFโโ) nos. 
23  1-3. 
24  Arrestees  may  remain at  CRF  anywhere  from  a  few  hours  to  a  few  days.  Arrestees 
25  are  then  either  released  from  custody,  or  transported  to  Kern  County  Superior  Court

B.  The  KCSD  Strip  Search  Policy  And  Practice. 
14 
I.  Strip/Visual  Body  Cavity  Search  โ  defined 
15      
A  strip/visual  body  cavity  search  requires  the  arrestee  or  prisoner  to  remove  all 
16 
clothing  so  as  to  permit  a visual  inspection  of the  breasts,  buttocks,  and  genitalia  of the 
17 
person  being  searched.  A  female  prisoner  must  expose  her  vagina;  a  male  prisoner must 
18 
lift  his  penis  and  scrotum for  visual  inspection.  A  prisoner  must  bend  over  and  separate 
19 
his/her  buttocks  cheeks,  to  squat  down  then  stand  back  up,  and  to  cough  three  times. 
20 
21  From  2003  to  present,  the  manner  of  strip  searching  prisoners  has  not  changed.  PSUF 
nos.  10-12. 
22 
23  2.  Who  Gets  Strip/Visual  Body  Cavity  Searched

25  (1)  arrestees  strip  searched  pursuant  to  Cal.  Penal  Code  ยง  4030ยฐ;  (2)  prisoners  strip

10 
Upon  Arrival 
11

12

17 
physical  contact  was  unavoidable.  PSUF  nos.  13-15,  20.

4.  The  Strip  Searches  Were  Often  Conducted  Under  Unsanitary  And 
Degrading  Conditions 
During group  strip  searches, prisoners  were exposed to unsanitary conditions.  They 
stood  and  walked  barefoot  on  dirty  floors  contaminated  with  bodily  fluids,  including 
blood,  with  material tracked  on  shoes  from outside  and  from within  other locations  of the 
facility.  Detainees  were  required  to  throw  their clothing  on  filthy  floors  and  at  times,  had 
to  re-dress  in  clothing  after  it  had  lain  on  the  dirty  floor.  PSUF  nos.  14,  15,  21. 
Menstruating  women  bled  on  themselves  and  on  the  floor.  The  floor  was  also  the 
repository  for  the  prisonersโ  clothes.  Male  and  female  prisoners  stood  barefoot  on  the 
same  floor that captured the prisonersโ  clothes  and bodily fluids.  Meanwhile, jail officials 
would  also  offer  their  comments,  mocking  and/or  humiliating  prisoners,  including 
disabled  prisoners  like  Mr.  Medina.  PSUF  Nos.  14,  15,  20-23.

14 
A.  Summary  Judgment  Standard. 
15      
Summary  adjudication  is  mandated  where  โthere  is  no  genuine  issue  as  to  any 
16 
material  factโ  and  โthe  moving  party  is  entitled  to  judgment  as  a  matter  of  law.โ 
17 
Fed.R.Civ.P.  56(c).  Summary  adjudication  or partial  summary judgment  is  permitted  by 
18 
both  the  Federal  and  Local  Rules.  F.R.Civ.P.  56(d);  Local  Rule  56-260(f). 
19 
B.  KCSDโs  Policy  Of  Strip  Searching  Persons  Ordered  Released  From 
20 
21  Custody,  Violated  The  Fourth  Amendment. 
22  The Fourth  Amendment  is  the  governing  standard.  Way  v.  County  of Ventura,  445 
23  F.3d  1157,  1161-62  (9" Cir.  2006)  (holding  that a  county jailโs  blanket  strip  search policy 
24  violated the Fourth  Amendment); Jordan  v.  Gardner,  986 F.2d  1521,  1524 (9th Cir.1993) 
25  (en banc)  (the โFourth Amendment  guarantees  the right of the  people to be  secure against 
26  unreasonable  searches,  and  its  protections  are  not  extinguished  upon  incarcerationโโ); 
27 
Thompson  v.  Souza,  111  F.3d  694,  699  (9th  Cir.  1997)  (same).

As  recently  reaffirmed  by  the  Ninth  Circuit, 
We  assess  the  constitutionality of  a  [strip]  search by  balancing  โthe  need  for 
the  particular  search  against  the  invasion  of personal  rights  that  the  search 
entails.โ  Bell  v.  Wolfish,  441  U.S.  520,  559,  99  S.Ct.  1861,  60  L.Ed.2d  447 
(1979).  This  requires  us  to  weigh  โthe  scope  of the  particular  intrusion,  the 
manner  in  which  it  is  conducted,  the  justification  for  initiating  it,  and  the 
place  in  which  it  is  conducted.โ  Id. 
Way  v.  County  of Ventura,  445  F.3d  at  1160. 
Unquestionably,  defendants  cannot  justify  its  (former)  policy  of  subjecting  all 
prisoners  who  have been  ordered  released  to  a  strip  search  upon  their arrival  at  the  Lerdo 
jail.  The  persons  subjected  to  the  search,  e.g.,  Mr.  Lopez  and  Mr.  Medina,  were  ordered 
released  from  custody.  At  the  point  the  release  order  issued,  defendantsโ  justification  for 
13 
any  search  of  plaintiffs  was  necessarily  minimized.  And  when  one  considers  the 
14 
especially  intrusive  nature  of  a  strip/visual  body  cavity  search  (Way,  445  F.3d  at  1160) 
15      
the  policy  cannot be justified  under  the  Fourth  Amendment.  Young  v.  City of Little  Rock,

alternatives  and  demonstrate that  the  statutory  intrusion  on the  cherished  right of privacy 
15      
is  drawn  with  narrow  specificity.โ  41  Cal.3d  at  953. 
16 
Defendants  cannot offer  any  compelling  justification  for providing  privacy  to  one 
17 
group  of prisoners  strip  searched  (ยง  4030(4/)  arrestees),  but  not to  prisoners  strip  searched 
18 
upon  their  arrival  at  the  Lerdo jail.  An  argument  of  administrative  convenience,  i.e.,  it 
19 
was  easier and/or  less  costly  to  provide  privacy to  the  ยง  4030(f)  prisoners  than  those like 
20 
21  plaintiffs,  fails.  โIt  is  now  well  settled  that  administrative  burden  does  not  constitute  a 
compelling  state  interest  which  would justify  the  infringement  of  a  fundamental  right.โ 
22 
23  Central  Valley  Chap.  7th  Step  Foundation  v.  Younger,  95  Cal.  App.  3d  212,  238  (1979) 
24  (defendantsโ  procedure  of  sending  arrest records  to  public  employers  without  editing  out 
25  any  arrest  which  did  not  result  in  a  conviction  is  prima  facie  violation  of  the  state 
26  constitutional right  of privacy,  and  administrative burden of screening  and  editing  before 
27  complying  with  the  requests  for  records  insufficient  justification).  An  administrative 
28 
13 
P LAINTIFFSโ  MEMORANDUM  OF LAW IN  SUPPORT  OF  MOTION FOR PARTIAL SUMMARY JUDGMEhoo.wep 
Case  1:07-cv-00474-DLB  Document  69 _  Filed  11/07/08  Page  19  of  20 
convenience  โjustificationโ  is  also impeached by  the experience  of other jails,  PSUF nos. 
27-30,  and  defendantsโ  October  2007  policy  change  โ  defendants  now  provide  privacy 
to  Lerdo jail  arrivals.  PSUF  no.  26. 
F.  The  Entity  Defendants  Are  Liable  For  The  Constitutional  Violations. 
I.  Federal  Liability 
When a  plaintiff  shows  that  her  rights  were  violated  by  a  municipal  policy  that 
caused  the  constitutional  violation,  or  an  established  pattern  or  practice  or  custom,  the 
entity  is  liable.  Monell  v.  New  York  Dept.  of Soc.  Servs.,  436  U.S.  658,  690-91  (1978); 
Chew  v.  Gates,  27  F.3d  1432,  1444  (9"  Cir.  1994).  The  policies  challenged  here  โ strip 
searches  of  inmates  ordered  released  by  a  court  and  routine  strip  searches  of  Lerdo  jail 
arrivals  in  groups  โ  are  all  policies  for  which  the  County  of  Kern  and  the  Kern  County 
Sheriff's  Department  are  responsible  under Monell.  Craft  v.  County  of San  Bernardino, 
13 
468  F.  Supp.  2d  1172,  1176  (C.D.  Cal.  2006)  (County  held  liable  based  on  its  pre- 
14 
arraignment and post-release  strip  search  policies);  Davis  v.  City  of Camden, 657  F.  Supp. 
15      
396,  402-404  (D.  N.J.  1987)  (same);  Ford  v.  City  of Boston,  154  F.  Supp.2d  131  (D. 
16 
Mass.  2001)  (same). 
17 
2.  State  Liability 
18 
Because the  strip  searches  were  performed by County  employees  acting  within the 
19 
course  and  scope  of  their  employment,  the  entity  defendants  are  liable,  pursuant  to  Cal. 
20 
21  Govโt  Code  ยง  815.2(a).  Robinson  v.  Solano  County,  278  F.3d  1007,  1016  (9"  Cir.  2002) 
22  (en  banc)  (California  โhas  rejected  the  Monell  rule  and  imposes  liability  on  counties 
23  under  the  doctrine  of respondeat  superior  for  acts  of county  employees.โ);  Perez  v.  City 
24  of Huntington  Park,  7  Cal.  App.  4th  817,  821  (1992)  (A  public  entity  is  liable  under  the 
25  doctrine  of  respondeat  superior  for  the  acts  of its  agents,  even  if the  plaintiff is  โunable 
26  to  identify  which  employee  committed  the  wrongful  act.โ). 
27  HI 
28 
14 
P LAINTIFFSโ  MEMORANDUM  OF LAW IN  SUPPORT  OF  MOTION FOR PARTIAL SUMMARY JUDGMEhoo.wep 
Case  1:07-cv-00474-DLB  Document  69 _  Filed  11/07/08  Page  20  of  20 
IV.  CONCLUSION. 
For the reasons  stated above,  Plaintiffs request that  the Court grant partial summary 
judgment or summary adjudication,  finding that defendantsโ  policies  of (1)  strip  searching 
inmates  in  groups  without  individual  privacy,  (2)  strip  searching  court-ordered  releasees 
upon  return  from  court,  violated  plaintiffsโ  state  and  federal  constitutional  rights. 
DATED:  November  7,  2008 
LITT,  ESTUAR,  HARRISON  &  KITSON,  LLP 
ROBERT  MANN  &  DONALD  W.  COOK 
Attorneys  for  Plaintiffs 
Cet  J  bol. 
 Donald  W.  Cook

1 I.  INTRODUCTION 
2 This lawsuit having come before this Court for a hearing, pursuant to this 
3 Courtโs Preliminary Approval Order, dated February 23, 2011 (the โPreliminary 
4 Approval Orderโ) to consider and determine the matters set forth in the 
5 Preliminary Approval Order; and due notice of said hearing having been published 
6 and given; and all entities that made timely objections to the proposed settlement 
7 set forth in the Settlement Agreement made and entered into on October 26, 2010, 
8 and described in the Class and Settlement Notice, having been given an 
9 opportunity to present such objections to the Court; and the Court having 
10 considered the matter, including all papers filed in connection therewith, and the 
11 oral presentations of counsel at said hearing; and good cause appearing, 
12   IT IS HEREBY ORDERED, ADJUDGED AND DECREED: 
13 1.  Each term and phrase used in this Final Order of Approval and 
14 Settlement shall have the same definition and meaning as in the Settlement 
15 Agreement, as follows: 
16 a.  โAdministratorโ means the Class Administrator Gilardi & Co., 
17 LLC, as agreed upon by the parties and as to be appointed by 
18 the Court, to review and determine the validity and amount of 
19 claims submitted by a Settlement Class Member (โSCMโ) (as 
20 defined herein), according to the procedures set forth herein. 
b.  The โBar Dateโ is the date by which any SCM who wishes to

Approval and Settlement), objections to this Settlement

1 Agreement, or request to be excluded from the class (opt-out).

1 becomes final. The Judgment will be deemed final only upon

for exclusion pursuant to the terms of the Settlement

2 custody; (b) were subjected to a strip and/or visual body cavity

5 (c) whose strip searches were conducted pursuant to KCSDโs 
blanket policy, practice and/or custom to regularly conduct
