1 II.  SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT APPROVED BECAUSE FAIR, 
ADEQUATE AND REASONABLE 
2
3.  The settlement of this lawsuit was not the product of collusion 
3
between Plaintiffs and Defendants or their respective counsel, but rather was the 
4
result of armโs-length negotiations conducted in good faith by the parties and their 
5
counsel, with the assistance of an independent mediator. 
6
4.  The Classโs satisfaction with the settlement is reflected in the claim 
7
statistics. There were 36,075 total identified class members in the Countyโs 
8
database, 29,678 of whom had a mailing address.  After re-mailing returned 
9
mailings, the Class Administrator was able to mail successfully to 22,917 such 
10
members. There were 7,961 timely Claim Forms filed, which is over 34% of class 
11
members reached through the mail. (See Solรณrzano Decl., ยถยถ3-10.) If the total 
12
36,075 class members are counted, this is a claim rate of 22%. According to 
13
Plaintiffsโ counsel, who have handled several of these cases, this is on the high end 
14
of claim rates. (See Declaration of Barrett S. Litt, ยถ5.) There were only two 
15
objections (addressed in Section VII, infra) and 15 opt-outs (addressed in Section 
16
VI, infra) , which means that, even if opt-outs are considered individuals 
17
dissatisfied in some form with the result (a conclusion not borne out by the content 
18
of the opt-outs), less than 1/20 of 1% of class members expressed any type of 
19
arguable dissatisfaction. Litt Decl., ยถ6.  This is a highly favorable reaction by the 
20
class to the settlement. See, e.g., Hughes v. Microsoft Corp., 2001 WL 34089697, 8 
21
(W.D.Wash. 2001) (court found that the โclass members overwhelmingly 
22
support[ed] the settlementโ where there were over 37,000 notices sent out, 2,745 
23
class members participated in the settlement, โonly nine objections were 
24
submittedโ, and there were 86 timely opt-outs and over 20 additional defective or 
25
untimely opt-outs;  โthese indicia of the approval of the class of the terms of the 
26
27
            5               
28
 
 
 

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 151    Filed 08/31/11   Page 7 of 23
   
1 settlement support a finding of fairness under Rule 23โ), citing Hanlon v. Chrysler 
2 Corp., 150 F.3d 1011, 1027 (9th Cir.1998) (despite vigorous objections and appeal 
3 by objectors, โfact that the overwhelming majority of the class willingly approved 
4 the offer and stayed in the class presents at least some objective positive 
5 commentary as to its fairnessโ; court did not abuse its discretion in approving 
6 settlement). 
7 5.  The Settlement Agreement and the settlement set forth therein โ 
8 attached to the Preliminary Approval Order in this case โ are hereby approved and 
9 found to be fair, adequate, reasonable, in the best interest of the Class as a whole, 
10 and in satisfaction of Rule 23 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure and due 
11 process requirements. 
12 III.  CERTIFICATION OF STRIP SEARCH CLASSES 
13 6.  The Court has previously certified Strip Search Classes under Fed. R. 
14 Civ. P. 23(b)(3) for damages and monetary relief.  Class Members have a right to 
15 opt out of the settlement.  The Court hereby reaffirms the class definitions as set 
16 forth in the Class Certification Order of April 1, 2009, and reiterated in the 
17 Settlement Agreement, including the class period of March 27, 2005, to October 1, 
18 2007. 
19 7.  The Court reaffirms that all the criteria of Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a) and 
20 (b)(3) are met for all the classes settled herein.  Specifically, the Court finds that all 
21 the criteria of Rule 23(a) are met, to wit, 1) that the class is so numerous that 
22 joinder of all members individually is impracticable, 2) that there are questions of 
23 law or fact common to the class, 3) that Plaintiffsโ claims are typical of the claims 
24 of Class Members, and 4) that the persons representing the class must be able fairly 
25 and adequately to protect the interests of all members of the class. The Court 
26 further finds, pursuant to the provisions of Rule 23(b)(3) that 1) the common 
27
            6               
28
 
 
 

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 151    Filed 08/31/11   Page 8 of 23
   
1 factual and legal issues predominate over any such issues that affect only 
2 individual Class Members, and 2) that a class action is superior to other available 
3 methods for the fair and efficient adjudication of the controversy. The Court 
4 further concludes that nothing in the partiesโ settlement alters, but rather, if 
5 anything, reinforces, the prior conclusions it reached regarding the desirability of 
6 the class action mechanism as a means of resolving the claims in this case. 
7 IV.  NOTICE 
8 8.  As required by this Court in its Preliminary Approval Order: (a) Class 
9 and Settlement Notice, and Claim Forms, were mailed by first-class mail to all 
10 Class Members for whom addresses could be determined, and to all potential Class 
11 Members who requested a copy; and (b) Class and Settlement Notice was 
12 published as set forth in the Settlement Agreement and in the Preliminary 
13 Approval Order, all as more fully set forth in the Declaration of Tricia M. 
14 Solorzano.  
15 9.  The notice given to the class is hereby determined to be fully in 
16 compliance with requirements of Rule 23 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 
17 and due process, and is found to be the best notice practicable under the 
18 circumstances and to constitute due and sufficient notice to all parties entitled 
19 thereto. 
20 10.  Due and adequate notice of the proceedings having been given to the 
21 Class and a full opportunity having been offered to the Class to participate in the 
22 hearing, it is hereby determined that all Class Members, except those who have 
23 opted out of the settlement, listed in the Declaration of Julia C. White, are bound 
24 by this Final Order of Approval and Settlement. 
25 V.  CLAIMS FILED 
26 11.  The claims filing postmark deadline was on July 13, 2011.  As of 
27
            7               
28
 
 
 

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 151    Filed 08/31/11   Page 9 of 23
   
1 August 12, 2011, the Class Administrator has received 7,961 timely Claim Forms 
2 and 111 late Claim Forms. Solorzano Decl., ยถ10.  Of the 111 late Claim Forms, 21 
3 were Post-Release Class members. 
4 12.  The Court will allow the valid late claims to be considered and paid if 
5 received by the Claims Administrator by August 26, 2011. 
6 VI.  OPT-OUTS 
7 13.  There were 14 unequivocal opt-outs. Solorzano Decl., ยถ11.  This 
8 figure does not include 1 individual who subsequently retracted [his/her] opt-out. 
9 14.  As class members have opted out, Plaintiffsโ counsel have attempted 
10 to contact opt-outs to see if they had any questions that could be cleared up. 
11 Declaration of Julia C.  White, ยถ2.  Counsel was able to find contact information 
12 for 12 of the individuals. White Decl., ยถยถ2(a), (c), (d), (e).  Based on these contacts, 
13 Plaintiffsโ counsel have been able to determine the nature of most if not all of the 
14 reasons the opt-outs were filed. 
15 15.  Six individuals indicated that they believed they were never strip 
16 searched. White Decl., ยถ2(d).  One additional individual indicated he was never 
17 incarcerated in Kern County Jail. White Decl., ยถ2(e).  As such, these people should 
18 not be considered opt-outs even if they filed an opt-out request, as they do not 
19 qualify as class members at all because a condition of membership in each class is 
20 that the person was strip searched by Kern County. 
21 VII.  OBJECTIONS 
22 16.  There have been two objections to the settlement in this matter.  
23 17.  The first objection, by Gregory McClellan, was dated March 24, 2011, 
24 prior to the deadline for filing objections.  A copy of Mr. McClellanโs objection 
25 was previously filed with the Court on July 13, 2011.  Mr. McClellan also filed a 
26 claim form.  According to Mr. McClellan, he was strip searched on three occasions 
27
            8               
28
 
 
 

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 151    Filed 08/31/11   Page 10 of 23
   
1 (twice on 11-09-2006, and once on 11-16-2006).  He objects to the settlement 
2 amount due him, which he indicates is $200, and instead is seeking $1,500.00. He 
3 cites no case law and gives no particular factual reason why he is entitled to 
4 $1,500, as opposed to the amount he is due to receive as a result of this settlement. 
5 18.  The second objection, by Sean Robbins, was dated June 8, 2011, prior 
6 to the deadline for filing objections.  A copy of Mr. Robbinsโ objection was 
7 previously filed with the Court on July 13, 2011.   He also filed a claim form, and 
8 he is due $200 under the settlement. According to Mr. Robbins, he was strip 
9 searched on multiple occasions during the booking process, during inmate transfers 
10 and on return from court.  Mr. Robbins also claims that he was strip searched by 
11 female officers. He objects to the settlement amount due him, but does not provide 
12 an amount to which he believes he is due. 
13 19.  The settlement of this lawsuit was not the product of collusion 
14 between Plaintiffs and Defendants or their respective counsel. Rather, it was the 
15 result of bona fide and armโs-length negotiations conducted in good faith by the 
16 parties and their counsel with the assistance of an independent mediator, who is a 
17 retired United States District Judge. 
18 Plaintiffsโ counselsโ efforts prior to settlement were extensive, and involved 
19 all that occurs in a case that is litigated up to the eve of trial. The work performed 
20 included: 1) extensive investigation of the underlying circumstances, including 
21 speaking with scores of class members; 2) discovery including three sets of 
22 requests for production of documents, interrogatories and multiple depositions; 4) 
23 multiple summary judgment motions by both sides, on all of which Plaintiffs 
24 prevailed; 5) a successful contested motion to certify the classes; 6) retention of 
25 data consultants and extensive analysis of computerized jail data; 7) contested 
26 motions to certify an interlocutory appeal; and 8) attendance and work associated 
27
            9               
28
 
 
 

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 151    Filed 08/31/11   Page 11 of 23
   
1 with four day-long mediation sessions. 
2 Any settlement requires compromise by both parties and involves the 
3 weighing of several considerations.  One significant factor in settlement is to take 
4 into account the risks associated with proceeding through to trial.  The issues 
5 involved are complex areas of constitutional law in an arena where considerable 
6 deference is given to jail officials. The settlement in this case encompassed two 
7 categories of class members. At the time this lawsuit was filed, the law was not 
8 settled in either of the areas encompassed by the suit.  For the Group Strip Search 
9 class, there is very little law stating that a strip search in a group setting is in and of 
10 itself a constitutional violation.  For the Post-Release class, in the course of the 
11 lawsuit, there were developments that can fairly be stated as problematic for 
12 Plaintiffs.  Those cases, namely Bull v. City & County of San Francisco, 595 F.3d 
13 964, 966 (9th Cir. 2010); Powell v. Barrett, 541 F.3d 1298 (11th Cir.2008); and 
14 Florence v. Bd. of Chosen Freeholders of County of Burlington, 621 F.3d 296 (3d 
15 Cir. 9/21/2010), cert. granted, 2011 WL 202772 (4/4/2011), all demonstrated 
16 substantial risk and uncertainty for Plaintiffs in what is now unsettled legal terrain.  
17 Further, the authority upon which Plaintiffs were able to rely was relatively scant, 
18 and emanated from the body of law whose validity is at least called into question 
19 by Bull, Powell and Florence. 
20 The financial terms of the settlement are very favorable to class members. 
21 Post-release class members receive $1500 for a first time and $750 for a second 
22 offense. This is considerably higher than the average recovery in many other strip 
23 search class actions. While this is partly explained by the scale of the other cases 
24 compared to this one, the fact remains that class members are receiving very 
25 favorable payments. In addition, those for whom searches would have otherwise 
26 been legal under Plaintiffsโ theories had they been conducted in privacy (i.e., those 
27
            10               
28
 
 
 

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 151    Filed 08/31/11   Page 12 of 23
   
1 strip searched in groups), are receiving money, including Messrs. McClellan and 
2 Robbins. 
3 The reason for the difference in values for the two groups - $1500 for post-
4 release versus $200 for group strip search โ  is primarily that the very act of strip 
5 searching post-release is (Plaintiffs contended) illegal. In contrast, Plaintiffs did 
6 not contend that the act of strip searching those searched in groups was illegal, 
7 only the manner of the search. Since most jails provide a variety of settings in 
8 which inmates are nude in front of each other and in front of guards, the damages 
9 for group searches are relatively minimal compared to damages for one illegally 
10 strip searched. 
11 The results in this case cannot be judged solely by the monetary component 
12 of the settlement. The County ceased all strip search practices addressed in this 
13 settlement. That is a major accomplishment, particularly in light of the standing 
14 limitations imposed on such cases. Tens of thousands of future inmates have been 
15 spared the โembarrassing and humiliating experienceโ, and โextensive intrusion on 
16 personal privacyโ, that a strip search, โregardless of how professionally and 
17 courteously conductedโ, necessarily entails. In some cases, they will not be strip 
18 searched at all (post-release inmates) and in others, if they are strip searched, it will 
19 be done with much greater privacy. 
20 Unlike most class actions, Plaintiffs and the classes they represent were 
21 persons charged with crimes and, thus, not people generally considered 
22 sympathetic or desirable by the public at large.  This makes any potential jury 
23 verdict speculative at best. 
24 With regard to Mr. Robbinsโ objection that he was strip searched by female 
25 guards, this was not a claim raised in the lawsuit. More importantly, the Ninth 
26 Circuit has held that visual body strip searches of male inmates by female guards 
27
            11               
28
 
 
 

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 151    Filed 08/31/11   Page 13 of 23
   
1 are not per se unlawful. See Grummett v. Rushen, 779 F.2d 491, 495-96 (9th 
2 Cir.1985) (pat-down searches of male inmates that included groin area by female 
3 guards do not violate Fourth Amendment); Michenfelder v. Sumner, 860 F.2d 328, 
4 332, 334 (9th Cir.1988) (occasional visual strip searches of male inmates by 
5 female guards do not violate Fourth Amendment; โ[o]ur circuit's law respects an 
6 incarcerated prisoner's right to bodily privacy, but has found that assigned 
7 positions of female guards that require only infrequent and casual observation, or 
8 observation at distance, and that are reasonably related to prison needs are not so 
9 degrading as to warrant court interferenceโ ); Jordan v. Gardner, 986 F.2d 1521, 
10 1524-26 (9th Cir. 1993) (policy that male guards would routinely engage in 
11 โclothed body searchesโ of women inmates, which entailed a search up to several 
12 minutes, running the guardโs hands over the female inmateโs clothed body from the 
13 neck to the feet, โpush[ing] inward and upward when searching the crotch and 
14 upper thighsโ, and flattening the breast, violated the Eighth Amendment; the record 
15 established that that โwomen experience unwanted intimate touching by men 
16 differently from men subject to comparable touching by womenโ, and that many of 
17 the women inmates at WCCW suffered had โhistories of sexual or physical abuse 
18 by menโ). Had Mr. Robbins wished to pursue such a claim for himself, he had that 
19 right, but it is not a valid objection to this settlement. 
20 20.  Based on the foregoing, the Court overrules the objections by Gregory 
21 McClellan and Sean Robbins. 
22 VIII. ALLOCATION AND DISTRIBUTION OF SETTLEMENT FUND 
23 21.  The Court hereby approves the Settlement Agreement. The Court 
24 finds that Defendantsโ proposed payment of the following amounts (each of which 
25 is in addition to the other) are within the range of what would constitute a fair, 
26 reasonable, and adequate settlement in the best interests of the class as a whole: 
27
            12               
28
 
 
 

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 151    Filed 08/31/11   Page 14 of 23
   
1 (a)  A person who was subjected for the first time during the class 
2 period (between March 27, 2005, and October 1, 2007) to a 
3 Kern County strip search after a Court ordered him or her to be 
4 released from all pending charges, and the person was in fact 
5 entitled to immediate release based on that order, will receive a 
6 payment of $1500 (subject to certain possible adjustments 
described below in ยถ2(d)). 
7
(b)  A person who was subjected for a second time during the class 
8
period (between March 27, 2005, and October 1, 2007) to a 
9
Kern County strip search after a Court ordered him or her to be 
10
released from all pending charges, and the person was in fact 
11
entitled to immediate release based on that order, will receive a 
12
payment of $750 in addition to the $1500 for the first strip 
13
search (again subject to certain possible adjustments described 
14
below in ยถ2(d)). No additional payments will be made to 
15
persons subjected to more than two such searches. 
16
(c)  A person who was strip searched in a group while in Kern 
17
County custody will receive a one time only payment 
18
(regardless of the number of times the person was strip searched 
19
in a group) of $200 (subject to certain possible adjustments 
20
described below in ยถ2(d)). 
21
(d)  Notwithstanding the amounts set forth above to be paid to each 
22
class member, the parties have agreed to a maximum payout for 
23
each class, the amount of which was derived from their joint 
24
estimate that claims are unlikely to exceed approximately 28% 
25
of the class members (and, based on past experience, will likely 
26
be meaningfully lower than that). Accordingly, the amounts to 
27
            13               
28
 
 
 

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 151    Filed 08/31/11   Page 15 of 23
   
1 be paid Class Members (not including class representatives) 
2 will be adjusted if the amount to be awarded eligible Class 
3 Members in either the Post-Release or Group Strip Search who 
4 make claims exceeds the total amount to be paid to that Class. 
5 In that event, the amount that members of that class receive will 
6 be adjusted on a pro-rated basis, which would result in payment 
to individual Class Members of amounts lower than those set 
7
forth above. The total amount paid to Post-Release Class 
8
Members is capped at $2,335,830.00, and if claims exceed that, 
9
they will be adjusted on a pro-rated basis so that the total 
10
payment to such Post-Release Class Members (first and second 
11
time combined) will not exceed that total. The amount paid to 
12
Group Strip Search Class Members is capped at $2,016,000.00, 
13
and if claims exceed that, they will be adjusted on a pro-rated 
14
basis so that the total payment to such Group Strip Search Class 
15
Members will not exceed that total. 
16
(e)  Class administration costs, as described below at Section X. 
17
(f)  $2,000,000 in attorneysโ fees, plus class counsel costs not to 
18
exceed $65,000. 
19
(g)  $30,000 damages award to each Named Plaintiff, of whom 
20
there are three, as identified below at Section IX. 
21
22.  The Administrator shall make payments to SCMs who have filed 
22
timely claims in accordance with this Final Approval Order within a reasonable 
23
time, with a goal of within 120 days after the Effective Date. If a check to a SCM 
24
is not cashed within three months of its mailing, the Administrator shall hold the 
25
funds for six additional months, during which time it shall make reasonable efforts 
26
to contact the person to whom the un-cashed check was written to make 
27
            14               
28
 
 
 

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 151    Filed 08/31/11   Page 16 of 23
   
1 arrangements for its cashing or reissuance. Any such funds not cashed within one 
2 year of its mailing shall revert to Defendants. 
3 IX.  NAMED PLAINTIFFSโ DISTRIBUTION 
4 23.  The class representatives are Marsial Lopez, Sandra Chavez, and 
5 Theodore Medina.  The Court awards each of the Named Plaintiffs $30,000.  The 
6 Named Plaintiffs will not otherwise participate in the claims process involving 
7 SCMโs, or receive any other payment under the terms of the Settlement 
8 Agreement. 
9 24.  The Court concludes that this award is justified because the Named 
10 Plaintiffs made contributions to the class as a whole, justifying awards to them 
11 higher than those to the general class. In addition, the Named Plaintiffsโ 
12 individualized damages claims, including special damages, are a factor in the 
13 determination of the sum they receive. Such determinations cannot reasonably be 
14 made for class members in general without unduly consuming funds for 
15 administrative costs that will otherwise be available for distribution to Class 
16 members. Any fees due Class Counsel for their representation of the Named 
17 Plaintiffs are encompassed within the Class Fund Attorneysโ Fees referenced 
18 herein. 
19 X.  CLASS ADMINISTRATION 
20 25.  The Court reaffirms the retention of Gilardi & Co., LLC (โGilardiโ) as 
21 Class Administrator to administer the distribution of the Class and Settlement 
22 Notice. The Court authorizes the payment, to be made immediately by the 
23 Defendants to cover Gilardiโs expenses to date.  The Court also authorizes payment 
24 of Gilardiโs further expenses by the Defendants related to class administration, 
25 distribution of settlement checks to Class Members, and handling of payments to 
26 Claimants with Liens as set forth in the Settlement Agreement. 
27
            15               
28
 
 
 

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 151    Filed 08/31/11   Page 17 of 23
   
1 26.  As part of the overall costs of Class Administration, the Court 
2 authorizes payment by Defendants of any expenses for a Special Master as set 
3 forth in the Settlement Agreement, should retention of a Special Master become 
4 necessary.  No further order of this Court is required to pay Class Administration 
5 costs.  Such payment shall be separate from the payment of Named Plaintiffs, 
6 attorneysโ fees and costs, and payments to class members. 
7 XI.  LIEN PROVISIONS 
8 27.  Consistent with the terms of the Settlement Agreement, the Class 
9 Administrator shall deduct from any claim certain payment amounts owed by a 
10 Claimant with Liens for any liens or court orders for restitution, child support, 
11 debts to county and statutory liens. The Class Administrator will make payment to 
12 Kern County, the proper payee and/or their designee for those payment amounts 
13 deducted as set forth in this paragraph. The Defendants shall prepare a list of the 
14 liens or orders applicable to each Claimant with Liens. That list will be provided to 
15 the Administrator, which will be responsible to confirm the list of such liens.  The 
16 following procedures shall apply to the liens. 
17 a.  For Claimants with Liens, the payment disbursement letter 
18 accompanying any claim check sent to them shall include a 
19 notice of that amount, specifying the nature of the lien and the 
20 purported amount of the lien. The Notice shall include advising 
21 the claimant of his or her right to contest the lien and advise 
22 him or her of the procedures to do so. The Notice will advise 
23 the Claimant with Liens that they have 30 days from the date of 
24 receipt of such notice (based on the postmark of said notice) to 
25 file a Notice Contesting Lien, and of the procedure to contest 
26 the lien. A form Notice Contesting Lien shall be provided to 
27
            16               
28
 
 
 

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 151    Filed 08/31/11   Page 18 of 23
   
1 each Claimant with Liens, to be prepared by the Administrator 
2 subject to approval by the parties, which will be used to contest 
3 the lien.  The Notice Contesting Lien shall specify the grounds 
4 for the objection, and copies shall be sent to Class Counsel, 
5 Defendantsโ counsel and the Claims Administrator. 
6 b.  First, the SCM, Class Counsel and Defendantsโ Counsel will 
7 attempt to resolve the objection by meet and confer conference.  
8 In the event the objection cannot be resolved in that fashion, the 
9 Special Master agreed to pursuant to ยถ49 of the Settlement 
10 Agreement will be empowered to resolve any lien disputes 
11 under this paragraph. To participate as a class member, any 
12 Claimant with Liens will be deemed to have agreed that the 
13 Special Masterโs determination shall be binding and non-
14 appealable, and that fact shall be included in the letter sent to 
15 Claimants with Liens. Such a claimant may present his or her 
16 contentions and supporting documents in writing to the Special 
17 Master. The Special Master will decide the validity of the lien, 
18 and may request recommendations from each sideโs counsel 
19 before doing so. 
20 c.  Despite the amount of any lien, no Claimant with Liens shall 
21 have to pay more than 50% of his/her class fund payment 
22 towards the lien, which ensures that the claimant will receive 
23 funds for his/her claim regardless of the amount of any lien.  
24 d.  The cost of the Special Master shall be borne by the Defendants 
25 as part of the Class Administration costs. 
26 28.  The Court approves the use of the liens under the terms set forth 
27
            17               
28
 
 
 

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 151    Filed 08/31/11   Page 19 of 23
   
1 above, which will reduce the portion of the settlement provided to any SCM to 
2 whom these provisions apply. Any government recordation of such liens or debts 
3 shall be adjusted to the extent necessary to reflect the reduction resulting from the 
4 pay down of the liens or debts effectuated by this provision. 
5 XII.  SPECIAL MASTER 
6 29.  The Court reaffirms the appointment of retired United States District 
7 Judge Raul A. Ramirez as the Special Master in this case. 
8 XIII. CLASS COUNSEL 
9 30.  The Court reaffirms the appointment of Barrett S. Litt and Paul J. 
10 Estuar of Litt, Estuar & Kitson, LLP, as Class Counsel. 
11 XIV. CLASS FUND ATTORNEYSโ FEES 
12 31.  As set forth in the Settlement Agreement, Defendants shall pay a one-
13 time only lump sump payment of $2,000,000 + costs (Two Million Dollars + 
14 actual costs) issued to Litt, Estuar & Kitson, LLP, which payment is inclusive of 
15 fees and costs.  This payment represents a full and final settlement of all past, 
16 present and future attorneysโ fees and all past, present and future ordinary and 
17 extraordinary costs.  It shall be paid as specified in ยถ34, infra. 
18 32.  The Court has reviewed the Plaintiffsโ counselโs claim for attorneysโ 
19 fees and finds them well within the accepted range for class fund fees. 
20 33.  The Court finds the partiesโ agreement regarding attorneysโ fees and 
21 costs to be reasonable, and awards the requested fees and costs. It addresses the 
22 issue in a separate order approving the fees and cost request herein. 
23  
24
25
26
27
            18               
28
 
 
 

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 151    Filed 08/31/11   Page 20 of 23
   
1 XV.  FORM OF PAYMENT OF NAMED PLAINTIFFSโ DISTRIBUTION 
AND ATTORNEYSโ FEES 
2
34.  Within 30 days after the Effective Date, Defendants or their insurers 
3
will issue a check that will include the approved attorneysโ fees and costs and the 
4
funds awarded to the class representatives in a single check.  Alternatively 
5
Defendants or their insurers may make a single wire transfer to the Litt, Estuar & 
6
Kitson, LLP Client Trust Account that will include the approved attorneysโ fees 
7
and costs, and the funds awarded to the class representatives in a single transfer 
8
(hereafter the โClass Rep/Fee Transferโ) within thirty (30) days of the Effective 
9
Date. 
10
XVI. GENERAL PROVISIONS 
11
35.  Claim forms not received by August 26, 2011, shall not be paid, 
12
although such persons shall nonetheless be bound by this Order. 
13
36.  All class members except those who timely filed opt-outs shall be 
14
bound by this Order. 
15
37.  Except as otherwise provided in this Order, each party shall bear its 
16
own costs, expenses and attorneysโ fees. 
17
38.  The use of the masculine gender herein is construed to include the 
18
feminine and/or the neuter where applicable. The use of the singular herein is to be 
19
construed to include the plural where applicable. The use of the plural herein shall 
20
be construed to include the singular where applicable. 
21
39.  Any disputes regarding the right of a claimant or class member to 
22
qualify for payment under Order shall be resolved by the Special Master. 
23
40.  The Court reserves and maintains jurisdiction over this settlement and 
24
its provisions, and over the claims administration and distribution of the funds. 
25
Disagreements between the parties on any disputes or unresolved aspects of this 
26
27
            19               
28
 
 
 

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 151    Filed 08/31/11   Page 21 of 23
   
1 Order shall be subject to mediation before the mediator who has mediated this case 
2 to date. If mediation is not successful, the matter shall be brought to this Court for 
3 resolution. 
4 41.  At the conclusion of the Class Distribution, the Class Administrator 
5 shall submit a report to the Court summarizing the payments made to the Class, 
6 and seeking any final administrative costs to be approved. 
7 XVII.   FINAL RESOLUTION 
8 42.  The monetary relief provided for in the Settlement Agreement shall 
9 compensate for all alleged violations of rights and all claims by the Plaintiff class 
10 members that were or could have been brought in this civil action under any theory 
11 of liability related to allegedly unlawful strip searches of those within the class 
12 definitions contained herein, except as to monetary damages for those class 
13 members who choose to opt out.   
14 43.  The Court hereby dismisses the lawsuit on the merits, with prejudice, 
15 and without further costs, with such dismissal subject only to compliance by the 
16 Parties with the terms and conditions of the Settlement Agreement and this Final 
17 Order of Approval and Settlement. 
18 44.  Plaintiffs, including their agents, attorneys and assigns, are hereby 
19 severally and permanently barred and enjoined, to the fullest extent permitted by 
20 law, from filing, commencing, instituting, maintaining, prosecuting or participating 
21 in a lawsuit or any other proceeding against the Defendants, including the 
22 employees, entities, agents, attorneys and insurers of Defendants, involving or 
23 based on any of the claims encompassed by this Settlement and Order, including 
24 specifically claims on behalf of any class member whose claims are covered by 
25 this Settlement and Order.  
26 45.  The Named Plaintiffs and each Class Member waive all rights or 
27
            20               
28
 
 
 

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 151    Filed 08/31/11   Page 22 of 23
   
1 benefits which he or she now has or in the future may have under the terms of 
2 California Civil Code ยง1542, arising from, alleged in, or pertaining to the claims 
3 that were asserted in the Lawsuit, specifically claims for strip searches and/or 
4 visual body cavity searches. Section 1542 reads: 
5 โA general release does not extend to claims which the creditor does not 
6 know or suspect to exist in his or her favor at the time of executing the 
7 release, which if known by him or  her must have materially affected his or 
8 her settlement with the debtor.โ 
9 46.  Plaintiffs have not relied upon the advice of Class Counsel as to the 
10 legal and/or tax consequences of this settlement, the payment of any money by the 
11 Defendants or the distribution of the Settlement Funds.  
12 47.  Neither this Final Order of Approval and Settlement, the Settlement 
13 Agreement, nor any of its terms or the negotiations or papers related thereto shall 
14 constitute evidence or an admission by any Defendant that any acts of wrongdoing 
15 have been committed, and they shall not be deemed to create any inference that 
16 there is any liability therefore. Neither this Final Order of Approval and 
17 Settlement, nor the Settlement Agreement, nor any of its terms or the negotiations 
18 or papers related thereto shall be offered or received in evidence or used for any 
19 purpose whatsoever, in this or any other matter or proceeding in any court, 
20 administrative agency, arbitration, or other tribunal, other than as expressly set 
21 forth in the Settlement Agreement.

24 /// 
25 /// 
26 ///

            21               
28

1 48.  Pursuant to Rule 54(b) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, the 
2 Court finds that there is no just reason for delay and therefore directs entry of this 
3 Final Order of Approval and Settlement. Inasmuch as this disposes of all claims 
4 asserted in the Lawsuit, the Court further directs the Clerk to enter an order of 
5 dismissal pursuant to F.R.Civ.P Rule 41(a)(1)(2).

{00868293.DOC}
1
               
28 
 
AMENDED PRELIMINARY APPROVAL ORDER 
29   
 
30 

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 130    Filed 02/23/11   Page 2 of 12
   
1  Upon review and consideration of the Settlement Agreement (a copy of 
2  which is attached to this Order as Exhibit A) and the exhibits attached thereto (the 
3  โSettlement Agreementโ) made and entered into on January 26, 2011, between the 
4  Named Plaintiffs in the above-captioned action (the โClass Representativesโ), 
5  individually and as representatives of the classes certified in this case, and the 
6  Defendants, County of Kern et al.,  
IT IS HEREBY ORDERED, ADJUDGED AND DECREED THAT: 
7 
I.  PRELIMINARY APPROVAL OF SETTLEMENT 
8 
1.  This Order incorporates by reference the definitions in the Settlement 
9 
Agreement (Exhibit A), and also incorporates Exhibits B through D, thereto. All 
10 
terms defined therein shall have the same meaning in this Order. The Court has 
11 
jurisdiction over this settlement pursuant to the Order of Conditional Dismissal 
12 
from the Ninth Circuit attached as Exhibit E.  
13 
2.  The Settlement Agreement is hereby preliminarily approved, subject 
14 
to further consideration thereof, and final approval, at or after the Fairness Hearing 
15 
provided for below. The Court finds that Defendantsโ proposed payment of the 
16 
following amounts (each of which is in addition to the other) are within the range 
17 
of what would constitute a fair, reasonable, and adequate settlement in the best 
18 
interests of the Class as a whole: 
19 
(a) A person who was subjected for the first time during the class period 
20 
(between March 27, 2005, and October 1, 2007) to a Kern County 
21 
strip search after a Court ordered him or her to be released from all 
22 
pending charges, and the person was in fact entitled to immediate 
23 
release based on that order, will receive a payment of $1500 (subject 
24 
to certain possible adjustments described below in ยถ 2(d)). 
25 
(b) A person who was subjected for a second time during the class period 
26 
(between March 27, 2005, and October 1, 2007) to a Kern County 
27 
 
{00868293.DOC}
2
               
28 
 
AMENDED PRELIMINARY APPROVAL ORDER 
29   
 
30 

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 130    Filed 02/23/11   Page 3 of 12
   
1  strip search after a Court ordered him or her to be released from all 
2  pending charges, and the person was in fact entitled to immediate 
3  release based on that order, will receive a payment of $750 in addition 
4  to the $1500 for the first strip search (again subject to certain possible 
5  adjustments described below in ยถ 2(d)). No additional payments will 
6  be made to persons subjected to more than two such searches. 
(c) A person who was strip searched in a group while in Kern County 
7 
custody will receive a one time only payment (regardless of the 
8 
number of times the person was strip searched in a group) of $200 
9 
(subject to certain possible adjustments described below in ยถ 2(d)). 
10 
(d) Notwithstanding the amounts set forth above to be paid to each class 
11 
member, the parties have agreed to a maximum payout for each class, 
12 
the amount of which was derived from their joint estimate that claims 
13 
are unlikely to exceed approximately 28% of the class members (and, 
14 
based on past experience, will likely be meaningfully lower than that). 
15 
Accordingly, the amounts to be paid Class Members (not including 
16 
class representatives) will be adjusted if the amount to be awarded 
17 
eligible Class Members in either the Post-Release or Group Strip 
18 
Search who make claims exceeds the total amount to be paid to that 
19 
Class. In that event, the amount that members of that class receive 
20 
will be adjusted on a pro-rated basis, which would result in payment 
21 
to individual Class Members of amounts lower than those set forth 
22 
above. The total amount paid to Post-Release Class Members is 
23 
capped at $2,335,830.00, and if claims exceed that, they will be 
24 
adjusted on a pro-rated basis so that the total payment to such Post-
25 
Release Class Members (first and second time combined) will not 
26 
exceed that total. The amount paid to Group Strip Search Class 
27 
 
{00868293.DOC}
3
               
28 
 
AMENDED PRELIMINARY APPROVAL ORDER 
29   
 
30 

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 130    Filed 02/23/11   Page 4 of 12
   
1  Members is capped at $2,016,000.00, and if claims exceed that, they 
2  will be adjusted on a pro-rated basis so that the total payment to such 
3  Group Strip Search Class Members will not exceed that total. 
4  (e) Class administration costs. 
5  (f) $2,000,000 in attorneysโ fees and costs, plus class counsel costs not to 
6  exceed $65,000. 
(g) $30,000 damages award to each Named Plaintiff, of whom there are 
7 
three. 
8 
3.  The Court approves the publication of summary class notice, as set 
9 
forth in the Settlement Agreement.  
10 
4.  Defendants shall pay the Class Administrator all sums necessary to 
11 
effectuate the terms of the Settlement Agreement and this Order, as set forth in the 
12 
Settlement Agreement. 
13 
5.  The Court preliminarily concludes that the terms of the Settlement 
14 
Agreement satisfy the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 23(e) and due process 
15 
requirements.  
16 
II.  DEADLINES FOR NOTICE, FILING OBJECTIONS AND OPT-
17 
OUTS, AND DATE OF FAIRNESS HEARING 
18   
6.  The Court has set the following dates for purposes of this class action:

Below are questions and answers designed to explain to you information about 
this lawsuit, including how to proceed to file a claim or otherwise participate in the 
Settlement process. 
1. What Is The Class Action Lawsuit About? 
This lawsuit involves the former policy and/or practice of the Kern County Jail of 
a) strip searching inmates (i.e., requiring inmates to remove all clothing and submit to a 
visual inspection, usually including a visual inspection of their breasts, genitals and 
rectum) in a group with other inmates, and b) strip searching inmates who became 
entitled to release from custody after going to court. The Class Period covers March 27, 
2005, through October 1, 2007 (when the policy was stopped). 
2. Who Is A Member Of The Class? 
You are a member of the class if you meet the definition of either of the classes 
(summarized above and set forth fully in the judgeโs orders), and your claim can be verified 
from the records of the Kern County Sheriffโs Department, 
Kern County must have a record of your being in custody so that officials can 
identify you individually by true name and other methods of identification, and ascertain 
that you qualify as someone who is a member of the class. Such records are the sole and 
final way it is determined who is a member of the class. 
You have received this Notice either because (a) County of Kern records indicate 
that you may be in the class, or (b) you contacted the Class Administrator in the belief 
that you are in the class. Whether or not you qualify as a class member will be based 
upon records of the County of Kern. If those records do not contain your name and show 
you to be within the definition of the class, you will not qualify. 
3. What Is The Purpose Of This Notice? 
You have a right to know about a proposed Settlement of this class action lawsuit 
and about all of your options before the Court decides whether to give final approval to 
the Settlement. Your rights may be affected by this lawsuit. 
This information is being sent to every known person who is or may be a member 
of the class based upon the last known address available from the records of the Kern 
County Sheriffโs Department, and otherwise publicized to reach class members. 
This Notice explains the lawsuit, the Settlement, your legal rights, what benefits 
are obtained, who is eligible and how to file a claim. 
The Court in charge of the case is the United States District Court for the Eastern 
District of California, located in Fresno,  California. The case is known as  Lopez v, 
Youngblood et al.,  Case No. CV-F-07-0474 DLB. The people who brought the case are 
called Plaintiffs, and the people they sued are called Defendants. 
EXHIBIT C

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB Document 125-4 Filed 01/22/11 Page 4 of 10 
4. Why Is This A Class Action? 
In a class action, one or more persons, called the Class Representative(s), sue on 
behalf of a group of people who have similar claims - the Class Members. One court 
then resolves the issues for all Class Members, except for those who exclude themselves 
from the class. 
5. Why Is There A Settlement? 
This case has been going on for a very long time. Instead of continuing with the 
case, both sides have agreed to a Settlement. That way, both sides are able to avoid the 
risks and costs of a trial or appeal, the case can be resolved immediately, and the benefits 
of the Settlement can be made immediately available to the Class Members. The Class 
Representatives and their attorneys think that the proposed Settlement is fair to the Class 
Members and the parties in the case, and think that the terms of the Settlement are a fair, 
reasonable and adequate resolution of this matter. Because this is a settlement, the 
Defendants do not formally admit liability, but they nonetheless agree to pay money to 
class members. 
6. Are There Lawyers Representing You? 
The Court has approved lawyers (called "Class Counsel") to collectively represent 
you. You will not be asked to pay your own personal money for the services of these 
attorneys and their associates and staff in litigating this case and negotiating this 
Settlement. Instead, the lawyers will seek payment from the defendants, subject to final 
approval of the Court, as is described further below. Only Class Counsel may act on 
behalf of the class, However, that does not prevent you from hiring your own lawyer to 
advise you personally about your rights, options or obligations as a Class Member in this 
lawsuit. If you want to be represented by your own lawyer, you may hire one at your 
own expense. 
7. What Does The Settlement  Provide9 
 
The Settlement provides for the following payments to class members in three 
tiers: 
a. A person who was subjected for the first time during the class period (between 
March 27, 2005, and October 1, 2007) to a Kern County strip search after a 
Court ordered him or her to be released from all pending charges, and the 
person was in fact entitled to immediate release based on that order, will 
receive a payment of $1500 (subject to certain possible adjustments described 
below in ยถ 8). 
b. A person who was subjected for a second or more time during the class period 
(between March 27, 2005, and October 1, 2007) to a Kern County strip search 
after a Court ordered him or her to be released from all pending charges, and 
the person was in fact entitled to immediate release based on that order, will 
receive a payment of $750 in addition to the $1500 for the first strip search

(again subject to certain possible adjustments described below in ยถ 8). If 
someone was strip searched after being ordered released more than two times 
during the Class Period, s/he will not receive additional money for those 
searches. 
c.  A person who was strip searched in a group while in Kern County custody 
during the Class Period will receive a one time only payment (regardless of 
the number of times the person was strip searched in a group) of $200 (subject 
to certain possible adjustments described below in ยถ 8). 
In addition, the Agreement provides for the following other payments: 
a) Separate payment by Defendants of settlement administration fees. 
b) Separate payment by Defendants of a total of $90,000 to the three 
individuals ($30,000 each) who were Named Plaintiff and Class 
Representatives, and whose individual damages could be assessed prior to 
Settlement. These plaintiffs will receive more under the Settlement than 
other Class Members because of the role that they played in the litigation, 
and because of individualized damages determinations made in their cases. 
The Court will finally approve whether to allow this amount or a different 
(but not higher) amount. 
C) (cid:9) An award of attorneysโ fees, to be separately paid by the Defendants, in the 
amount of $2,000,000, subject to the final approval of the Court, and costs 
of litigation not to exceed $65,000. 
As a result of this case, Kern County Jail no longer engages in routine strip 
searches in groups or of those who are ordered by a court to be released, and are entitled 
to immediate release. 
8. (cid:9) What Are The Possible Adjustments To The Amounts Class 
Representatives Receive? 
As indicated above, class members are to receive a fixed amount of money, which 
may be adjusted under certain circumstances.  An adjustment would only occur if the 
number of claims substantially exceeds what the parties expect based on past  experience 
in cases of this kind. Specifically, the total amount paid to Post-Release Class Members 
(first and second time combined) is capped at approximately $2,335,000, and amount 
paid to Group Strip Search Class Members is capped at approximately  $2,015,000 (each 
rounded to the nearest $5000). If  claims exceed those amounts for either class, they will 
be adjusted on a pro-rated basis so that the total payment for that class will not exceed its 
maximum. 
The reason for this maximum is that the defendants bargained that the settlement 
would not cost them more than a certain amount, so this adjustment assures them that the 
total cost of the settlement will not exceed a certain amount.

The parties expect that the amount allocated for each class will be sufficient to

adjusted. Thus, it is important that you understand that this is possible. 
Even if 100% of class members filed claims, and all were paid, post-release strip 
search class members would receive $420, and group strip search class members would 
receive $56. 
The Class Administrator shall deduct from any claim payment the amount owed by a 
claim participant for liens or court orders for restitution, child support, debts owed to the 
County of Kern or any statutory liens. By filing a Claim Form, you agree to allow the Class 
Administrator access to your records regarding child support or potential statutory liens. 
However, no more than 50% of the amount due to a claimant may be deducted to pay such 
restitution, debts or liens, so all qualifying claimants will receive some money even if such 
deductions occur. A Class Member from whom lien deductions will be taken will have the 
right to present evidence to a retired judge that s/he does not owe the money on which the lien 
is based; the retired judgeโs decision on that issue will be final. 
10. (cid:9) Will I Receive Anything From The Settlement? 
If it is verified that you are a Class Member, and you file an approved claim 
within the time set by the Court, you will be entitled to receive compensation in 
accordance with the schedule described above. 
IL. (cid:9) Do I Do To Get Money? 
If you wish to receive money from the Settlement, you must complete and submit 
the accompanying Claim Form. Read the instructions on the Claim Form carefully. All 
Claim Forms must be completed- . โAnd .stmarked (or received by the 
Administrator) no later than  _, 2011, but it is recommended that you complete 
and mail your Claim Form as soon as possible.  If you do not timely and properly 
submit your Claim Form, you will not receive any money  from the Settlement. if 
you need a copy of a Claim Form, please call   (toll free), or write to the

12. (cid:9) Can I Exclude Myself From The Settlement? 
If you do not want to be a member of the class, then you must take steps to get out 
of the class. This is called "excluding yourself" from, and sometimes is referred to as 
"opting out" of, the class.

13. What Do I Do To Exclude Myself From The Lawsuit? 
To exclude yourself, you must send a letter by First-Class mail clearly stating that 
you want to be excluded from Lopez v. Youngblood, et al.  Be sure to include your name, 
address, telephone number and signature. The name and address of your attorney is not 
sufficient.  You must mail your Exclusion Request, postmarked no later than 
,2011 to: 
Lopez v, Youngblood, et al.  Settlement Administrator 
____,CA 
You cannot exclude yourself on the phone or by email. If you are excluded, you 
will not be entitled to get any money from the Settlement, and you cannot object to the 
Settlement. Nor will you be legally bound by anything that happens in this lawsuit. 
Unless you exclude yourself from the class, you remain in the class and give up 
all of your rights against the Defendants except those available to you under this 
Settlement. That means that, if you donโt exclude yourself and you also donโt file a 
claim, you will receive no money but still lose your rights against the Defendants. So  be 
sure to file your claim. 
14. What Is The Release Of Claims? 
If you are a class member and have not excluded yourself from the class as 
described above, you are waiving all your rights to all claims during the class period 
related to strip searches by the Kern County Sheriffs Department falling within the 
Courtโs definition of the Classes, even those you are not aware of at present. This waiver 
includes a waiver of the provisions of California Civil Code ยง1542, which provides that 
"a general release does not extend to claims which the creditor does not know or suspect 
to exist in his or her favor at the time of executing the release, which if known by him or 
her must have materially affected his or her settlement with the debtor." By not 
excluding yourself, you will be giving up unsuspected claims in these areas related to 
strip searches by the Kern County Sheriffs Department. However, you will not be  giving 
up any other claim(s) that you may have against Kern County for conduct not covered by 
this Settlement (for example, a false arrest or battery by a police officer). 
15. If! Do Not Like The Settlement Or Object To The Attorneysโ Fees, 
How Do I Tell The Court? 
If you are and remain a Class Member, you can object to the Settlement if you do 
not like any part of it, or you may object to the request for Attorneysโ Fees. You must 
give the reason why you think that the Court should not approve the Settlement or the 
requested Attorneysโ Fees. A mere statement that "I object" will not be sufficient. Do not 
contact the Court orally to object. Rather, you  must send  a written statement with the 
case name and number  (Lopez v. Youngblood, et  al.,  Case No. CV-F-07-0474 DLB) at 
the top of the page. In addition,  provide your name, your address (just giving the address 
of an attorney who represents you is not sufficient), your telephone number, the date of 
arrest to the extent known, your signature and the reason why you object. If you are

longer affects you. If you do object, you should also file a claim form. 
17. When And Where Will The Court Decide Whether To Approve The 
Settlement And Attorneysโ Fees? 
The Court has scheduled the Fairness Hearing for 10:00 A.M. on   
2011, in the United States District Courthouse for the Eastern District of California, 2500 
Tulare Street, Fresno, CA 93721, in the courtroom of Magistrate Judge Dennis Beck, 
Courtroom No. 9. At this Hearing, Judge Beck will consider whether the Settlement is 
fair, reasonable and adequate, and will determine the amount of Attorneysโ Fees and 
costs to be awarded. If there are any objections, the Court will consider and rule on them. 
We do not know how long this process will take. We do not know if the Hearing will be 
continued. There will not be a new notice if it is. You may  speak at the Hearing with the 
permission of the Court, but only if you have submitted your comments or objections as 
described above. 
18. Do I Have To Come To The Hearing? 
No. You may, but need not, attend the Hearing. Class Counsel will answer any 
questions the Court may have. However, you may come if you choose, at your own 
expense. If you sent a written objection, you do not have to come to Court to talk about

19. May I Speak At The Hearing? 
You will not be heard unless you have submitted your comments or objections. 
You cannot speak at the Hearing if you exclude yourself. If you have submitted an 
objection, the Court will decide whether or not to hear from you verbally as well. 
20. What Happens If I Do Nothing At All? 
If you do nothing, your rights will be affected. You will be bound by the terms of 
the Settlement and you will be agreeing to a release of the claims that are contained in the 
Settlement. However, because you did not file a claim, you will not be entitled to any 
money from the Settlement, 
21. When Will I Receive Money From the Settlement? 
No money will be paid until after the Settlement is approved and all possibilities 
of appeal are completed. After that, it will likely take two to three months, and quite 
possibly more, to process all the claims, calculate the amount due to each Class Member 
and receive the money to send to the Class Members. 
If you file a claim and do not receive money within eight months after

want to send the Form in by certified mail so it can be verified, but you are not required 
to do so. 
Remember that it is possible that the Court will approve the settlement, but that 
there could be an appeal that would substantially delay any payment if it were successful. 
22. What Happens If There Is Not A Final Settlement? 
Under certain circumstances, it is possible the settlement might not go through 
(for example, if there are too many people who decide not to participate or if the court for 
some reason does not approve the settlement). In that situation, the case would go 
forward and go to trial.

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB     Document 91      Filed 03/31/2009     Page 1 of 32

19                                                                         )
20
On July 17, 2008, Defendants County of Kern, the Kern County Sheriffโs Office
21
(โKCSOโ), Donny Younglood and Mack Wimbish (โDefendantsโ) filed a joint motion for
22
summary adjudication.  On November 7, 2008, Defendants filed a second joint motion for
23
summary adjudication regarding court returnees, qualified immunity and Eleventh Amendment
24
immunity.  On November 7, 2008, Plaintiffs Marsial Lopez, Sandra Chavez, and Theodore
25
Medina filed their cross-motion for partial summary judgment and/or summary adjudication.  All
26
three motions were heard on December 19, 2008, before the Honorable Dennis L. Beck, United
27
28
1

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB     Document 91      Filed 03/31/2009     Page 2 of 32
1 States Magistrate Judge.1  Barrett Litt and Donald Cook appeared on behalf of Plaintiffs. 
2 Jennifer Thurston and Terence Cassidy appeared on behalf of Defendants.
3 BACKGROUND
4 Plaintiff Marsial Lopez, individually and as class representative, filed the instant civil
5 rights action on March 27, 2007.  On June 21, 2007, Plaintiffs Marsial Lopez, Sandra Chavez,
6 and Theodore Medina, individually and as class representatives, filed a First Amended
7 Complaint (โFACโ) against Defendants.  Plaintiffs seek injunctive relief and damages resulting
8 from the strip and/or visual body cavity searches of prisoners by the Kern County Sheriffโs
9 Department. 
10 The FAC pursues causes of action for violation of the Fourth, Eighth and Fourteenth
11 Amendments to the U.S. Constitution, violation of Article I, ยงยง 1, 7, 13 and 17 of the California
12 Constitution and state law violations.  Plaintiffs allege that Defendants maintained a policy of
13 indiscriminately strip/body cavity searching all or a large number of persons being processed into
14 the jail without limitation on the number of persons who can see, hear or observe the searches. 
15 Plaintiffs also allege that Defendants improperly strip searched detainees who had been ordered
16 released.
17 On July 17, 2008, Defendants filed a joint motion for summary adjudication regarding
18 group strip searches.  Defendants contend that the group strip searches at issue do not violate the
19 Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments.  In addition, Defendants argue that Plaintiffsโ equal
20 protection claim state law claims fail as a matter of law. 
21 Pursuant to a briefing schedule, Plaintiffs filed an opposition to the motion on September
22 16, 2008, along with a statement of disputed and undisputed facts and objections to the
23 declaration of Ian Silva.  On October 3, 2008, Defendants filed a reply and objections to the
24 Declaration of Paul J. Estuar filed in support of Plaintiffsโ motion. 
25 On November 7, 2008, Defendants filed their second joint motion for summary
26 adjudication regarding court returnees, qualified immunity and Eleventh Amendment immunity. 
27
1Plaintiffsโ motion to certify the class, Plaintiffsโ motion to strike and Plaintiffsโ motion to amend the FAC
28
also are pending before the Court. 
2

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB     Document 91      Filed 03/31/2009     Page 3 of 32
1 Defendants contend that (1) the searches of certain Plaintiffs who assert that their constitutional
2 rights were violated when they were subjected to strip searches after returning to the jail
3 following a court appearance in which they were ordered released were reasonable; (2)
4 Defendants Yougblood and Wimbish are immune from liability because the law was not clearly
5 established that searching post-arraignment detainees in small groups violates Plaintiffsโ rights
6 under the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments and violates the Equal Protection Clause; (3) the
7 Sheriff is a state actor and immune from a ยง 1983 suit; and (4) the County should be dismissed
8 from this action.
9 Plaintiffs filed an opposition to Defendantsโ second motion on November 21, 2008, along
10 with a statement of disputed and undisputed facts and the Declaration of Barrett S. Litt and
11 Donald W. Cook.  Defendants filed a reply and objections to Plaintiffsโ statement of facts on
12 December 5, 2008. 
13 On November 7, 2008, Plaintiffs also filed their cross-motion for partial summary
14 judgment and/or summary adjudication.  Plaintiffs seek a determination that (1) KCSOโs policy
15 of strip searching persons ordered released from custody violated the Fourth Amendment; (2)
16 KCSOโs policy of group strip searching prisoners violated the Fourth Amendment; (3) the strip
17 search policies violated Plaintiffsโ state constitutional rights pursuant to Cal. Const. Art. I, ยง 1
18 (privacy), Cal. Const. Art. I, ยง 13 (unreasonable searches) and Cal. Const. Art. I, ยง 7 (equal
19 protection); and (4) the entity defendants are liable under federal and state law.
20 Defendants filed an opposition to Plaintiffsโ cross-motion for summary adjudication on
21 November 21, 2008, along with a statement of undisputed facts and objections to the declaration
22 of Donald W. Cook.  Plaintiffs filed a reply on December 6, 2008.
23 FACTUAL BACKGROUND
24 A. Jail Facilities
25 Defendant KCSO operates four different jail facilities.  These facilities include Central
26 Receiving Facility (โCRFโ), Ridgecrest, Mojave, and Lerdo.  The main function of the CRF
27 facility is booking and receiving arrestees coming straight off the street.  Since at least 2003, pre-
28
3

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB     Document 91      Filed 03/31/2009     Page 4 of 32
1 arraignment misdemeanor arrestees at CRF were not subject to strip searches on a routine basis,
2 either before or after their first court appearance.  
3 If not released from CRF, arrestees are transported to the Kern County Superior Court
4 (โSuperior Courtโ) for their initial court appearance.  After their initial court appearance,
5 arrestees are transported back to CRF for either (a) housing in the Lerdo jail if remanded to
6 custody or (b) to be released from custody at CRF.  Post-arraignment prisoners, including those
7 serving sentences, are housed at Lerdo.  Lerdo is divided into four different divisions: pretrial,
8 maximum-medium (โmax-medโ), female minimum and male minimum.
9 B. KCSO Inmate Searches
10 Procedure D of KCSO Policy C-500 specifies that persons in the general inmate
11 population (not pre-arraignment detainees):
12 may be subjected to a strip search or visual body cavity search in the following
situations:  
13
โข After an inmate has left the facility and returned (i.e., medical appointment, court,
14 etc.)
โข After an inmate laborer has completed their assigned duties inside or outside the
15 facility and is returning to their housing area.

1 DISCUSSION
2 A. Summary Judgment Standard
3 Summary judgment is appropriate when no genuine issue of material fact exists and the
4 moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.  Celotex Corp. v. Catrett, 477 U.S. 317
5 (1986).  โIf the party moving for summary judgment meets its initial burden of identifying for the
6 court the portions of the materials on file that it believes demonstrate the absence of any genuine
7 issues of material fact,โ the burden of production shifts and โthe non moving party must set forth,
8 by affidavit or as otherwise provided in Rule 56, โspecific facts showing that there is a genuine
9 issue for trial.โโ  T.W. Electric Service, Inc. v. Pacific Elec. Contractors Ass'n, 809 F.2d 626, 630
10 (9th Cir. 1987) (quoting Fed.R.Civ.P. 56(e)).  As to the specific facts offered by the nonmoving
11 party, the court does not weigh conflicting evidence, but draws all inferences in the light most
12 favorable to the nonmoving party.  Id. at 630-31.
13 If the moving party meets its initial responsibility, the burden then shifts to the opposing
14 party to establish that a genuine issue as to any material fact actually does exist.  Matsushita Elec.
15 Indus. Co. v. Zenith Radio Corp., 475 U.S. 574, 586 (1986).
16 In attempting to establish the existence of this factual dispute, the opposing party may not
17 rely upon the denials of its pleadings, but is required to tender evidence of specific facts in the
18 form of affidavits, and/or admissible discovery material, in support of its contention that the
19 dispute exists.  Fed. R. Civ. P. 56(e); Matsushita, 475 U.S. at 586 n.11.  The opposing party must
20 demonstrate that the fact in contention is material, i.e., a fact that might affect the outcome of the
21 suit under the governing law, Anderson v. Liberty Lobby, Inc., 477 U.S. 242, 248 (1986); T.W.
22 Elec. Serv.,809 F.2d at 630, and that the dispute is genuine, i.e., the evidence is such that a
23 reasonable jury could return a verdict for the nonmoving party, Wool v. Tandem Computers, Inc.,
24 818 F.2d 1433, 1436 (9th Cir. 1987).
25 In the endeavor to establish the existence of a factual dispute, the opposing party need not
26 establish a material issue of fact conclusively in its favor.  It is sufficient that the claimed factual
27 dispute be shown to require a jury or judge to resolve the partiesโ differing versions of the truth at
28 trial.  T.W. Elec. Serv., 809 F.2d at 630.  Thus, the โpurpose of summary judgment is to โpierce
7

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB     Document 91      Filed 03/31/2009     Page 8 of 32
1 the pleadings and to assess the proof in order to see whether there is a genuine need for trial.โโ 
2 Matsushita, 475 U.S. at 587 (quoting Fed. R. Civ. P. 56(e) advisory committeeโs note on 1963
3 amendments).
4 In resolving the summary judgment motion, the court examines the pleadings,
5 depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if
6 any.  Fed. R. Civ. P. 56(c). The evidence of the opposing party is to be believed, Anderson, 477
7 U.S. at 255, and all reasonable inferences that may be drawn from the facts placed before the
8 court must be drawn in favor of the opposing party, Matsushita, 475 U.S. at 587 (citing United
9 States v. Diebold, Inc., 369 U.S. 654, 655 (1962) (per curiam).  Nevertheless, inferences are not
10 drawn out of the air, and it is the opposing partyโs obligation to produce a factual predicate from
11 which the inference may be drawn.  Richards v. Nielsen Freight Lines, 602 F.Supp. 1224, 1244-
12 45 (E.D. Cal. 1985), aff'd, 810 F.2d 898, 902 (9th Cir. 1987).  
13 Finally, to demonstrate a genuine issue, the opposing party โmust do more than simply
14 show that there is some metaphysical doubt as to the material facts . . . .  Where the record taken
15 as a whole could not lead a rational trier of fact to find for the non-moving party, there is no
16 โgenuine issue for trial.โโ  Matsushita, 475 U.S. at 587 (citation omitted).
17 B. Discussion2
18 1. Fourth Amendment
19 In Count One, Plaintiffs contend that Defendants violated Plaintiffsโ rights to be secure in
20 their persons against unreasonable searches and seizures as guaranteed by the Fourth and
21 Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution.  FAC, at ยถ 46.  Plaintiffs seek
22 recovery of damages pursuant to 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983.  FAC, at ยถ 46. 
23 The Fourth Amendment protects prisoners from unreasonable searches and seizures. 
24 Strip searches that are excessive, vindictive, harassing, or unrelated to any legitimate penological

2 the United States Supreme Court nor the Ninth Circuit has yet held that prisoners retain no
3 privacy rights under the Fourth Amendment.  Hudson v. Palmer, 468 U.S. 517, 526 (1984)
4 (โFourth Amendment proscription against unreasonable searches does not apply within the
5 confines of the prison cell.โ) (emphasis added); Bell v. Wolfish, 441 U.S. 520, 558 (1979)
6 (โassuming [without deciding] that inmates, both convicted prisoners and pretrial detainees,
7 retain some Fourth Amendment rights upon commitment to a corrections facility . . . .โ); Somers
8 v. Thurman, 109 F.3d 614 (9th Cir. 1997).  The Ninth Circuit has found that prisoners retain a
9 limited right to bodily privacy.  Michenfelder, 860 F.2d at 333.
10 In analyzing whether searches of detainees violate the Fourth Amendment, the Supreme
11 Court set forth a balancing test in Bell, 441 U.S. at 559.  In Bell, the Supreme Court held that
12 visual body cavity searches of pre-trial detainees conducted after every contact visit with a person
13 from outside the institution did not violate the Fourth Amendment.  Id. at 558.  
14 The Bell court explained:
15 The test of reasonableness under the Fourth Amendment is not capable of precise
definition or mechanical application.  In each case it requires a balancing of the
16 need for the particular search against the invasion of personal rights that the
search entails.  Courts must consider the scope of the particular intrusion, the
17 manner in which it is conducted, the justification for initiating it, and the place in
which it is conducted.
18
Id. at 559.

placement in the general population.

18 searching detainees who have been ordered released.

26 staff to know which of the inmates are going to be released following their court appearances

9 2. Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment
10 In Count One of the FAC, Plaintiffs allege that Defendants violated their rights under the
11 Fourteenth Amendment to be free from unreasonable searches and seizures.  FAC, at ยถ 46. 
12 Defendants argue that the group searches at issue do not violate Plaintiffsโ rights under the Due
13 Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment and seek summary adjudication. 
14 In evaluating the constitutionality of conditions or restrictions of pretrial detention which
15 implicate only the deprivation of liberty without due process of law, the United States Supreme
16 Court has indicated that the proper inquiry is whether the conditions amount to punishment of the
17 detainee.  Bell, 441 U.S. at 535-37.  A court must decide whether the disability is imposed for the
18 purpose of punishment or whether it is but an incident of some other legitimate governmental
19 purpose.  Bell, 441 U.S. at 538.  Plaintiffs did not expressly oppose Defendantsโ due process
20 arguments and count one of the FAC does not expressly allege a due process violation premised
21 on the Fourteenth Amendment.  As Defendants contend, however, there are no facts to suggest
22 that any of the Plaintiffs were strip searched as a means for punishment.  Plaintiffs have failed to
23 demonstrate that the practice of searching inmates in small groups violates due process rights
24 under the Fourteenth Amendment.  Accordingly, to the extent that Plaintiffs have alleged a
25 Fourteenth Amendment due process violation regarding group strip searches, Defendantsโ motion
26 for summary adjudication as to this claim is GRANTED.

6 The Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment commands that no state shall
7 deny any person equal protection of the laws.  City of Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, 473
8 U.S. 432, 439 (1985).  Thus, all persons similarly situated should be treated alike.  Id.; Plyler v.
9 Doe, 457 U.S. 202, 216 (1982).  Dissimilar treatment of dissimilarly situated persons does not
10 violate Equal Protection. See Keevan v. Smith, 100 F.3d 644, 648 (8th Cir. 1996) (treatment of
11 dissimilarly situated persons in a dissimilar manner does not violate the Equal Protection
12 Clause); Barket, Levy & Fine, Inc. v. St. Louis Thermal Energy Corp., 21 F.3d 237, 242 (8th Cir.
13 1994).  
14 Plaintiffs challenge the unequal practice of providing privacy for pre-arraignment strip
15 searches, but not other strip searches conducted by Defendants.  Plaintiffs have offered no
16 authority to support their contention that pre-arraignment arrestees and post-arraignment persons
17 are similarly situated.  Plaintiffsโ attempt to equate the two by arguing that a personโs interest in
18 maintaining the privacy of his or her body cavities is the same for both arrestees and pre-trial
19 detainees is unpersuasive.  The Court agrees with Defendants that, in this context, pre-
20 arraignment arrestees are not similarly situated to post-arraignment detainees.  Compare Giles,
21 746 F.2d at 615 (โarrestees for minor offenses may be subjected to a strip search only if jail
22 officials have a reasonable suspicion that the particular arrestee is carrying or concealing
23 contraband or suffering from a communicable diseaseโ), with Bell, 441 U.S. at 546-47 & n. 28
24 (finding no basis to conclude that pretrial detainees pose any lesser security risk than convicted
25 inmates and applying constitutional rights enjoyed by convicted prisoners to pretrial detainees;
26 determining visual body cavity searches following contact visits did not violate Fourth
27 Amendment and could be conducted on less than probable cause).

20 5. Qualified Immunity
21 Defendants contend that the individual defendants, Youngblood and Wimbish, are
22 entitled to qualified immunity as to Plaintiffsโ constitutional claims.  โQualified immunity is โan
23 entitlement not to stand trial or face the other burdens of litigation.โโ Saucier v. Katz, 533 U.S.
24 194, 200 (2001) (quoting Mitchell v. Forsyth, 472 U.S. 511, 526 (1985)).  The Court evaluates a
25 defendant's qualified immunity defense using a two-step inquiry.  Id.  However, the Supreme
26 Court recently held that this two-step inquiry is no longer an inflexible requirement.  Pearson v.
27 Callahan, --- U.S. ----, ----, 129 S.Ct. 808, 818, 172 L.Ed.2d 565 (2009) (explaining โthat, while
28 the sequence set forth [in Saucier] is often appropriate, it should no longer be regarded as
23

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB     Document 91      Filed 03/31/2009     Page 24 of 32
1 mandatoryโ).  It is within our โsound discretion in deciding which of the two prongs of the
2 qualified immunity analysis should be addressed first in light of the circumstances in the
3 particular case at hand.โ Id.
4 Under Saucier's first prong, the court must determine whether, viewing the facts in the
5 light most favorable to the plaintiff, the government employees violated the plaintiff's
6 constitutional rights.  Saucier, 533 U.S. at 201.  If the court determines that a constitutional
7 violation has occurred, under Saucierโs second prong, it must determine whether the rights were
8 clearly established at the time of the violation. Id.  For a right to be clearly established, its
9 contours โ โmust be sufficiently clear that a reasonable official would understand that what he is
10 doing violates the right.โ โ Id. at 202 (quoting Anderson v. Creighton, 483 U.S. 635, 640
11 (1987)).  The protection afforded by qualified immunity โsafeguards โall but the plainly
12 incompetent or those who knowingly violate the law.โโ Brewster v. Bd. of Educ. of the
13 Lynwood Unified Sch. Dist., 149 F.3d 971, 977 (9th Cir.1998) (quoting Malley v. Briggs, 475
14 U.S. 335, 341 (1986)).
15 a. Group Searches
16 Fourth Amendment Claims
17 Defendants argue that Defendants Youngblood and Wimbish are entitled to qualified
18 immunity regarding the Fourth Amendment claims specific to group searches because there is
19 no clearly established case law. 
20 At a minimum, it is established that the Fourth Amendment protects prisoners from
21 unreasonable searches and seizures.  Michenfelder, 860 F.2d at 332 (strip searches that are
22 excessive, vindictive, harassing, or unrelated to any legitimate penological interest are not
23 reasonable).  It is also clear that prisoners retain a limited right to bodily privacy.  Michenfelder,
24 860 F.2d at 333.  However, under the second prong of Saucier, the inquiry is more
25 particularized.  The issue before the Court is whether the contours of the limited right to privacy
26 and the protection against unreasonable searches were sufficiently clear such that the individual
27 defendants could believe that group strip searches violated the Fourth Amendment rights of
28 post-arraignment detainees.
