documents.title: Order Regarding Motion for Entry of Judgment on Specified Claims and Certification of Claims for Appeal
documents.text:
Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 114    Filed 07/01/09   Page 1 of 8
1
2
3
4
5
6
 UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
7
EASTERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA
8
MARSIAL LOPEZ, et al., )  1:07cv0474 DLB
9 )
)
10 ) ORDER REGARDING MOTION FOR ENTRY
) OF JUDGMENT ON SPECIFIED CLAIMS
11 Plaintiffs, ) AND CERTIFICATION OF CLAIMS FOR
) APPEAL
12 v. )
)
13 DONNY YOUNGBLOOD, et al.,   ) (Document 94)
)
14 )
)
15 Defendants. )
                                                                        )
16
17 On April 28, 2009, Defendants County of Kern, Kern County Sheriffโs Office, Donny
18 Youngblood and Mack Wimbish filed the instant motion for entry of judgment pursuant to
19 Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 54(b).  The matter was heard on June 26, 2009, before the
20 Honorable Dennis L. Beck, United States Magistrate Judge.  Barrett Litt and Paul Estuar
21 appeared telephonically on behalf of Plaintiffs.  Jennifer Thurston and Terence Cassidy appeared
22 on behalf of Defendants.
23 BACKGROUND
24 Plaintiff Marsial Lopez, individually and as class representative, filed the instant civil
25 rights action on March 27, 2007.  On June 21, 2007, Plaintiffs Marsial Lopez, Sandra Chavez,
26 and Theodore Medina, individually and as class representatives, filed a First Amended
27 Complaint (โFACโ) against Kern County, the Kern County Sheriffโs Department, Kern County
28 Sheriff Donny Youngblood (officially and individually) and former Kern County Sheriff Mack
1

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 114    Filed 07/01/09   Page 2 of 8
1 Wimbish (individually).  Plaintiffs seek injunctive relief and damages resulting from the strip
2 and/or visual body cavity searches of prisoners by the Kern County Sheriffโs Department. 
3 The FAC contains six causes of action:  (1) damages pursuant to 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983
4 premised on unreasonable searches and seizures in violation of the Fourth and Fourteenth
5 Amendments of the U.S. Constitution; (2) damages pursuant to 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 premised on
6 violation Fourteenth Amendment equal protection guarantees; (3) violation of their equal
7 protection rights pursuant to Article I, ยง 7 of the California Constitution and unreasonable search
8 and seizure in violation of Article I, ยง 13 of the California Constitution; (4) damages pursuant to
9 California Civil Code ยง 52.1(b) and ยง 52(b) premised on violations of their rights under the
10 Fourth, Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments, Article I, ยงยง 1, 7, 13 and 17 of the California
11 Constitution, and California Penal Code ยง 4030; (5) violation of California Penal Code ยง 4030;
12 and (6) violation of mandatory duties under California Government Code ยง 815.6. 
13 On March 31, 2009, the Court issued an order on the partiesโ cross motions for summary
14 judgment.  In its Order, the Court: (1) granted Plaintiffs summary judgment/adjudication as to
15 KCSOโs policy of group strip searching prisoners in violation of the Fourth Amendment; (2)
16 granted Plaintiffs summary judgment/summary adjudication as to KCSOโs policy of strip
17 searching persons ordered released from custody in violation of the Fourth Amendment; (3)
18 granted Plaintiffsโ motion for partial summary judgment/summary adjudication regarding
19 violation of California Constitution, Article I, Section 1; (4) denied without prejudice
20 Defendantsโ motion for summary adjudication regarding Plaintiffsโ state law claims pursuant to
21 California Civil Code section 52.1; (5) granted Defendantsโ motion for summary adjudication
22 that Defendants Youngblood and Wimbish are entitled to qualified immunity regarding
23 Plaintiffsโ Fourth Amendment claims specific to group strip searches; (6) denied Defendantsโ
24 motion for summary adjudication that Defendants Youngblood and Wimbish are entitled to
25 qualified immunity regarding the searches of detainees upon return from court appearances after
26 they were ordered released; (7) denied Defendantsโ motion for summary adjudication against
27 Plaintiffsโ causes of action for ยง 1983 claims on the ground that the Sheriffs are state actors and
28
2

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 114    Filed 07/01/09   Page 3 of 8
1 are entitled to Eleventh Amendment immunity; and (8) denied Defendantsโ motion for summary
2 adjudication as to ยง 1983 claims asserted against the County.
3 On April 1, 2009, the Court also granted Plaintiffsโ motion for class certification.  The
4 Court certified the following classes:
5   Post-Release Class: Persons who, from March 27, 2005, up to October 1, 2007, or the
time of judgment or settlement of the case: (a) were in KCSD custody; (b) were taken
6 from jail to court; (c) became entitled to release after going to court; and (d) were strip
and/or vbc searched before release pursuant to KCSDโs blanket policy, practice and/or
7 custom to strip/vbc search all court returns, including those entitled to release.
8 Group Strip Search Class: Persons who, from March 27, 2005, up to October 1, 2007, or
the time of judgment or settlement of the case: (a) were in KCSD custody; (b) were
9 subjected to a strip and/or vbc search in a group with other inmates also being strip/vbc
searched, which search did not afford privacy from others; and (c) whose strip searches
10 were conducted pursuant to KCSDโs blanket policy, practice and/or custom to regularly
conduct strip/vbc searches in a group setting.
11
On April 28, 2009, Defendants Sheriff Donny Youngblood and former Sheriff Mack
12
Wimbish filed a notice of appeal as to the Courtโs determination that they were not entitled
13
Eleventh Amendment immunity as to Plaintiffsโ section 1983 claims.  The appeal was processed
14
to the Ninth Circuit on May 13, 2009, and has been assigned USCA Case Number 09-16006.  
15
On April 28, 2009, Defendants County of Kern, Kern County Sheriffโs Office, Donny
16
Youngblood and Mack Wimbish also filed the instant motion for entry of judgment pursuant to
17
Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 54(b).  Defendants move the Court to certify the following
18
issues for immediate appeal: (1) whether the County of Kern may be held liable under 42 U.S.C.
19
ยง 1983 for the policies of the Sheriff as they relate to operation of the jail; (2) whether strip
20
searching inmates in groups violated the Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution;
21
(3) whether strip searching inmates in groups violated Section 1 of the California
22
Constitution; and (4) whether strip searching inmates in groups forms an underlying basis for
23
liability under California Civil Code section 52.1.  Defendants applied for a stay as to the
24
remaining issues.  Defendants supported their motion with the declaration of counsel, Jennifer
25
Thurston.  
26
Plaintiffs filed their opposition to the motion on May 15, 2009, along with the declaration
27
of counsel, Barrett Litt.  
28
3

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 114    Filed 07/01/09   Page 4 of 8
1 Defendants filed a reply on May 22, 2009.  On that same date, Defendants filed a motion
2 for certification of issues for immediate interlocutory review pursuant to 28 U.S.C. ยง 1292, for
3 amendment of the Courtโs March 31, 2008, order and for a stay pending appeal.  Similar to the
4 Rule 54(b) motion, the motion for interlocutory review includes, but is not limited to the issue of
5 the constitutionality of group strip searches of post-arraignment detainees and inmates under the
6 Fourth Amendment and the issue of the Countyโs status as a potentially improper party based on
7 Eleventh Amendment immunity of the Sheriff defendants.  The interlocutory review motion was
8 heard on the same day as the instant motion.
9 DISCUSSION
10 A. Legal Standard
11 Rule 54(b) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure allows for the entry of final judgment
12 with respect to less than all parties or claims in an action if the court makes โan express
13 determination that there is no just reason for delayโ and expressly directs โentry of judgment.โ 
14 Fed. R. Civ. P. 54(b).1  In making a determination under Rule 54(b), the court must first
15 determine that it is dealing with a final judgment, which means a decision that is โan ultimate
16 disposition of an individual claim entered in the course of a multiple claims action.โ 
17 Curtiss-Wright Corp. v. General Elec. Co., 446 U.S. 1, 7 (1980); Sears, Roebuck & Co. v.
18 Mackey, 351 U.S. 427, 436 (1956).  Second, the court must determine whether there is any just
19 reason for delay.  Curtiss-Wright Corp., 446 U.S. at 7.  In sum, Rule 54(b) requires the presence
20 of three conditions: (1) multiple claims or multiple parties; (2) at least one claim or the rights and
21 liabilities of one party have been finally decided; and (3) there is no just reason for any delay in
22 entering judgment and allowing an appeal. See 10 Wright, Miller & Kane, Federal Practice and
23 Procedure: Civil 3d ยง 2656 (1998).
24
25
26
27 1Fed. R. Civ. P. 54(b) states: โWhen an action presents more than one claim for reliefโwhether as a claim,
counterclaim, crossclaim, or third-party claimโor when multiple parties are involved, the court may direct entry of a
28 final judgment as to one or more, but fewer than all, claims or parties only if the court expressly determines that there
is no just reason for delay.โ
4

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 114    Filed 07/01/09   Page 5 of 8
1 B. Analysis
2 1. Final Determination
3 Defendant County requests entry of judgment on the following: (1) the Countyโs section
4 1983 liability for the policies or customs of KCSO; and (2) the Courtโs determination that
5 searching inmates in groups is unconstitutional, including liability under the Fourth Amendment,
6 Article I, Section 1 of the California Constitution and California Civil Code section 52.1. 
7 Defendants contend that the Court has made final determinations on these โclaims.โ
8 Plaintiffs counter that Defendantsโ basis for an appeal falls short because, despite a liability
9 determination, there has been no damages determination.  As noted by Plaintiffs, the Ninth Circuit
10 has held that โa judgment is not final as to one entire claim under 28 U.S.C. ยง 1291, or under
11 F.R.Civ.P. 54(b) if it decides only liability and leaves open the question of relief.โ  Wolf v. Banco
12 Nacional de Mexico, S.A., 721 F.2d 660, 662 (9th Cir. 1983) (an appeal did not lie under Rule
13 54(b) where the judgment addressed liability on one claim but did not address any requested
14 damages or attorneyโs fees); cf. Liberty Mut. Ins. Co. v. Wetzel, 424 U.S. 737, 744 (1976)
15 (discussing ยง 1291 and indicating no finality where assessment of damages or awarding of other
16 relief remains to be resolved); Hain Pure Food Co., Inc. v. Sona Food Products Co., 618 F.2d 521,
17 522 (9th Cir. 1980) (discussing ยง 1292 and concluding that the determination of liability alone is
18 not a final judgment); United States v. Southern Pac. Transp. Co., 543 F.2d 676, 681 n. 5 (9th Cir.
19 1976) (district court decided only the issue of liability, without deciding what relief would be
20 appropriate, and therefore the judgment was not final as to one entire claim and not appealable
21 under ยง 1291).
22 As to the issues identified by the Defendants for entry of judgment, the Court has ruled on
23 the Countyโs section 1983 liability and the unconstitutional nature of the group strip searches,
24 without deciding what relief and/or damages would be appropriate.  Defendants have not
25 adequately addressed the absence of a damages ruling in their papers.2  At oral argument,
26
27 2Defendant County objected to the lateness of Plaintiffsโ opposition, noting it was due on May 12, 2009, but
was not filed and served electronically until May 15, 2009.  Based on the original hearing date of May 29, 2009,
28 Plaintiffsโ opposition was late pursuant to the Local Rules.  Local Rule 78-230(c) requires either personal service 14
days before the hearing or electronic service 17 days before the hearing.  However, Defendants were able to file a
5

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 114    Filed 07/01/09   Page 6 of 8
1 Defendants acknowledged that entry of judgment would place these issues in an unusual posture on
2 appeal where there has been no ruling on damages.  Absent a damage determination or resolution
3 as to relief, the Court finds that judgment is not final as to one entire claim and therefore not
4 appropriate for entry of judgment pursuant to Rule 54(b).  
5 2. No Just Reason to Delay Appeal
6 Defendants cite General Acquisition, Inc. v. GenCorp, Inc., 23 F.3d 1022, 1030 (6th Cir.
7 1994), which lists factors to consider when making a Rule 54(b) determination regarding a just
8 reason for delay.  In that case, the court noted that โ[n]o precise test exists for determining whether
9 there is a just reason to delay,โ but articulated factors for consideration to include:
10 (1) the relationship between the adjudicated and unadjudicated claims; (2) the
possibility that the need for review might or might not be mooted by future
11 developments in the district court; (3) the possibility that the reviewing court might
be obliged to consider the same issue a second time; (4) the presence or absence of a
12 claim or counterclaim which could result in set-off against the judgment sought to
be made final; (5) miscellaneous factors such as delay, economic and solvency
13 considerations, shortening the time of trial, frivolity of competing claims, expense
and the like.
14
Id. at 1030.  
15
Applying the General Acquisition factors, Defendants submit the declaration of counsel and
16
aver that (1) there is no factual or legal relationship between the matters not decided by the Court
17
or the issue of strip searching court โreleaseesโ and those issues sought to be appealed; (2) no
18
development in the trial court (outside of sua sponte reversal by the Court) will moot the need for
19
appellate review of the identified issues; (3) decisions on the appealed issues could streamline the
20
trial on the remaining issues, e.g., an appellate determination that the Sheriff acted for the state, not
21
the County, would preclude further litigation or a determination that group strip searches were
22
lawful would cut the lawsuit in half and reduce prospective class members to a โmere fractionโ; (4)
23
the trial could be greatly shortened if the County is successful because of the reduced number of
24
plaintiffs and issues; (5) the Courtโs time and the partiesโ time would be reduced and economic
25
resources preserved, including the need for notifying prospective class members; (6) the matter is
26
27
reply to the opposition on May 22, 2009, and have not demonstrated any prejudice resulting from the late-filed
28 opposition.  On May 26, 2009, the Court rescheduled the original hearing date to coincide with the hearing on
Defendantsโ motion pursuant to 28 U.S.C. ยง 1292(b).  
6

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 114    Filed 07/01/09   Page 7 of 8
1 being appealed by Youngblood and Wimbish as of right so there is little justification for failing to
2 obtain appellate review as to all ripe issues; and (7) the issues are distinct from those not appealed
3 and the Court of Appeals would not decide the same issue more than once.  Thurston Decl., ยถยถ 4,
4 7-8, 10-11.
5 In their briefing, Defendants miscite General Acquisition as a Ninth Circuit case, and
6 contend that the Court should apply these five factors.  General Acquisition is a case from the
7 Sixth Circuit and is not binding.  At a minimum, however, the Court โmust take into account
8 judicial administrative interests as well as the equities involved,โ including such factors โas
9 whether the claims under review [are] separable from the others remaining to be adjudicated and
10 whether the nature of the claims already determined [is] such that no appellate court would have to
11 decide the same issues more than once even if there were subsequent appeals.โ  Curtiss-Wright
12 Corp., 446 U.S. at 8 (noting that one factor may be offset by another).  
13 Plaintiffs counter that if Defendants appeal the post-release liability determination in the
14 future, granting a Rule 54(b) judgment โwould result in piecemeal appeals involving the same
15 basic set of facts.โ  Opposition, p. 7.  Plaintiffs contend that the asserted justifications for strip
16 searching persons post-release, which is not the subject of the instant motion, are the same as those
17 asserted for group strip searches and, thus, the Court of Appeals would have to review the same
18 evidence more than once.  A similarity of legal or factual issues weigh heavily against entry of
19 judgment under Rule 54(b) and such an order โwill be proper only where necessary to avoid a
20 harsh and unjust result.โ  Morrison-Knudsen Co., Inc. v. Archer, 655 F.2d 962, 965 (9th Cir.
21 1981).  Although Defendants argue that there is no factual similarity between the group search
22 class and the post-release strip search class, the Court notes that there is an overlap in asserted
23 justifications for the group searches and the post-release searches, which weighs against entry of
24 judgment. 
25 CONCLUSION
26 Based on the above, Defendantsโ motion for entry of judgment on specified claims and
27 certification of claims for appeal pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P. 54(b) is DENIED.  As the Court has
28
7

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB   Document 114    Filed 07/01/09   Page 8 of 8
1 declined to enter judgment pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P. 54 (b), the corresponding application for
2 stay also is DENIED.
3
4 IT IS SO ORDERED.                                                                                                     
5 Dated:      June 30, 2009                                  /s/ Dennis L. Beck                 
3b142 a                                                                     UNITED STATES MAGISTRATE JUDGE

)
15 Defendants. )
                                                                        )
16
17 On November 12, 2008, Plaintiffs filed the instant joint motion for leave to file a second
18 amended complaint.  The matter was heard on December 19, 2008, before the Honorable Dennis
19 L. Beck, United States Magistrate Judge.  Barrett Litt and Donald Cook appeared on behalf of
20 Plaintiffs.  Jennifer Thurston and Terence Cassidy appeared on behalf of Defendants Kern
21 County, the Kern County Sheriffโs Office, Sheriff Donny Youngblood (individually and in his
22 official capacity) and Former Sheriff Mack Wimbish (individually) (โDefendantsโ).
23 BACKGROUND
24 Plaintiff Marsial Lopez, individually and as class representative, filed the instant civil
25 rights action on March 27, 2007.  On June 21, 2007, Plaintiffs Marsial Lopez, Sandra Chavez,
26 and Theodore Medina, individually and as class representatives, filed a First Amended
27 Complaint (โFACโ) against Kern County, the Kern County Sheriffโs Department, Kern County
28 Sheriff Donny Youngblood (officially and individually) and former Kern County Sheriff Mack
1

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB     Document 90      Filed 03/31/2009     Page 2 of 5
1 Wimbish (individually).  Plaintiffs seek injunctive relief and damages resulting from the strip
2 and/or visual body cavity searches of prisoners by the Kern County Sheriffโs Department. 
3 The FAC contains six causes of action:  (1) damages pursuant to 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983
4 premised on unreasonable searches and seizures in violation of the Fourth and Fourteenth
5 Amendments of the U.S. Constitution; (2) damages pursuant to 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 premised on
6 violation Fourteenth Amendment equal protection guarantees; (3) violation of their equal
7 protection rights pursuant to Article I, ยง 7 of the California Constitution and unreasonable search
8 and seizure in violation of Article I, ยง 13 of the California Constitution; (4) damages pursuant to
9 California Civil Code ยง 52.1(b) and ยง 52(b) premised on violations of their rights under the
10 Fourth, Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments, Article I, ยงยง 1, 7, 13 and 17 of the California
11 Constitution, and California Penal Code ยง 4030; (5) violation of California Penal Code ยง 4030;
12 and (6) violation of mandatory duties under California Government Code ยง 815.6. 
13 On November 12, 2008, Plaintiffs filed the instant motion for leave to file a second
14 amended complaint.1  Plaintiffs seek to add a seventh cause of action under Article I, ยง1 of the
15 California Constitution for violations of their privacy rights.  Plaintiffs argue that the proposed
16 cause of action was โmistakenly omittedโ from the original complaint.  
17 Defendants filed a joint opposition on December 2, 2008.  Plaintiffs filed a reply on
18 December 5, 2008.
19 DISCUSSION
20 Federal Rule of Civil Procedure Rule 15(a) provides that the court โshould freely give
21 leave when justice so requires.โ  Fed. R. Civ. P. 15(a)(2).  The United States Supreme Court has
22 stated: 
23 [i]n the absence of any apparent or declared reason โ such as undue delay, bad faith or
dilatory motive on the part of the movant, repeated failure to cure deficiencies by
24 amendments previously allowed, undue prejudice to the opposing party by virtue of
allowance of the amendment, futility of amendment, etc. โ the leave sought should, as the
25 rules require, be โfreely given.โ
26
27
28 1Plaintiffsโ motion for partial summary judgment, Defendantsโ two joint motions for summary adjudication,
Plaintiffsโ motion to certify the class and Plaintiffsโ motion to strike also are pending before the Court. 
2

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB     Document 90      Filed 03/31/2009     Page 3 of 5
1 Foman v. Davis, 371 U.S. 178, 182 (1962).  The Ninth Circuit has summarized these factors to
2 include the following: (1) undue delay; (2) bad faith; (3) prejudice to the opponent; and (4)
3 futility of amendment.  Loehr v. Ventura County Cmty. Coll. Dist., 743 F.2d 1310, 1319 (9th Cir.
4 1984).  Leave to amend rests in the sound discretion of the trial court.  Swanson v. United States
5 Forest Serv., 87 F.3d 339, 343 (9th Cir. 1996).  Despite the policy favoring amendment under
6 Rule 15, leave to amend may be denied if the proposed amendment is futile or would be subject
7 to dismissal.  Saul v. United States, 928 F.2d 829, 843 (9th Cir. 1991).
8 Defendants object to the proposed amendment on two grounds: (1) prejudice and (2)
9 futility.  To demonstrate prejudice, Defendants point out that the instant motion follows the filing
10 of dispositive motions.  Defendants contend that Plaintiffs attempted to assert this new claim in
11 their Opposition to Defendants first motion for summary adjudication regarding strip searches. 
12 Defendants noted this impropriety in their reply of October 3, 2008.  Defendants then filed a
13 second summary adjudication motion on November 7, 2008, regarding qualified immunity,
14 Eleventh Amendment immunity and court returnees.  Defendants argue that Plaintiffs did not
15 seek to amend their complaint until November 12, 2008, โsome six weeks after Defendants first
16 called attention to their omission and after two dispositive motions were filed.โ  (Defs.โ Joint
17 Opp. to Plaintiffsโ Mot. to Amend Complaint 2).  
18 Defendants argue that the delay and related expense constitute prejudice, citing Ansam
19 Assocs., Inc. v. Cola Petroleum, Ltd., 760 F.2d 442, 446 (2d Cir. 1985) and Campbell v. Emory
20 Clinic, 166 F.3d 1157, 1162 (11th Cir. 1999).  Defendants citations are not instructive.  In
21 Ansam, the court upheld the denial of leave to amend due to prejudice associated with the close
22 of discovery and the filing of a motion for summary judgment.  However, the proposed claims in
23 Ansam involved an entirely new set of operative facts, a different period of time and a different
24 statute from the operative pleading.  Id. at 446.  Here, Plaintiffs propose to add a claim regarding
25 the right to privacy under the California Constitution.  This claim does not involve a new set of
26 facts, a different time period or even a different statute from the operative pleading.  For instance,
27 Plaintiffs partially base their fourth cause of action under Civil Code ยง 52.1(b) on an underlying
28 violation of Article I, ยง 1 of the California Constitution.  FAC, at ยถ 50.  
3

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB     Document 90      Filed 03/31/2009     Page 4 of 5
1 The instant case also differs from Campbell.  In that case, the court found prejudice and
2 undue delay inherent in an amendment asserted after the close of discovery and after dispositive
3 motions were filed, briefed, and decided.  Campbell, 166 F.3d at 1162.  The motions for leave to
4 amend in Campbell were filed more than one year after discovery had ended, after dispositive
5 motions had been filed, between five-and-six years after the lawsuits had begun and after the
6 plaintiff had been twice granted leave to amend.  In this case, the dispositive motions have not
7 been decided, this case has been pending for two years and Plaintiffs have not requested leave to
8 amend at any other time.
9 Defendants further contend that the original complaint did not โreasonablyโ place them
10 on notice that Plaintiffs intended to assert an independent ยง 1 claim.  Although Defendants
11 objected to the assertion of the section 1 claim in Plaintiffsโ cross-motion for summary judgment,
12 Defendants responded to it in their opposition to Plaintiffsโ cross-motion.  (Doc. 75).  Defendants
13 argued, in part, that just as Plaintiffsโ Fourth Amendment claim must fail, their Section 1 claim
14 must fail because the right of privacy established by Section 1 is not a broader protection than
15 that provided under the Fourth Amendment.  (Defs.โ Opp. Cross-Mot. Sum. Adjud. 18.) 
16 Several courts have indicated that in the search and seizure context, the Article I, ยง 1
17 privacy clause of the California Constitution has not been held to establish a broader protection
18 than that provided by the Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution.  See, e.g., Quon
19 v. Arch Wireless Operating Co., Inc., 529 F.3d 892, 903 (9th Cir. 2008) (the privacy protected by
20 Article I, Section 1 of the California Constitution is no broader in the area of search and seizure
21 than the privacy protected by the Fourth Amendment) (quoting Hill v. Natโl Collegiate Ath.
22 Assโn, 7 Cal.4th 1, 30 n.9 (1994)), rehโg denied, 554 F.3d 769 (2009); Sanchez v. County of San
23 Diego, 464 F.3d 916, 943 (9th Cir. 2006) (in search and seizure context, the Article I, Section 1,
24 privacy clause of the California Constitution has never been held to establish a broader protection
25 than that provided by the Fourth Amendment).  Accordingly, the Court finds no prejudice to the
26 proposed amendment as Defendants fully briefed their contentions under the Fourth Amendment.
27
28
4

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB     Document 90      Filed 03/31/2009     Page 5 of 5
1 Insofar as Defendants argue that the proposed amendment is futile because of the
2 reasonable nature of the searches at issue, the Court defers such determination until resolution of
3 the pending summary judgment motions.
4 Based on the above, Plaintiffsโ motion for leave to file a second amended complaint is
5 GRANTED.
6
7 IT IS SO ORDERED.                                                                                                     
8 Dated:      March 31, 2009                                  /s/ Dennis L. Beck                 
3b14 2  a                                                                   UNITED STATES MAGISTRATE JUDGE

documents.title: Order Granting Plaintiffs' Motion for Class Certification/Denying as Moot Plaintiffs' Motion to Strike/Setting Status Conference
documents.text:
Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB     Document 92      Filed 04/01/2009     Page 1 of 9
1
2
3
4
5
6
7
8  UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
9 EASTERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA
10 MARSIAL LOPEZ, et al.,  ) 1:07cv474 DLB
)
11 ) ORDER GRANTING PLAINTIFFSโ 
) MOTION FOR CLASS CERTIFICATION
12 Plaintiffs, ) (Document 33)
)
13 v. ) ORDER DENYING AS MOOT PLAINTIFFSโ
) MOTION TO STRIKE
14 ) (Document 47)
DONNY YOUNGBLOOD, et al.,  )
15 ) ORDER SETTING STATUS CONFERENCE
) May 4, 2009
16 Defendants. ) 9:00 a.m.
                                                                        ) Courtroom 9
17
18 On June 17, 2008, Plaintiffs Marsial Lopez, Sandra Chavez and Theodore Medina
19 (โPlaintiffsโ) filed the present motion for class certification.  Plaintiffs also filed a motion to
20 strike on July 28, 2008.  Both motions were heard on December 19, 2008, before the Honorable
21 Dennis L. Beck, United States Magistrate Judge.  Barrett Litt and Donald Cook appeared on
22 behalf of Plaintiffs.  Jennifer Thurston and Terence Cassidy appeared on behalf of Defendants
23 Kern County, the Kern County Sheriffโs Office, Sheriff Donny Youngblood (individually and in
24 his official capacity) and Former Sheriff Mack Wimbish (individually) (โDefendantsโ).
25 BACKGROUND
26 Plaintiff Marsial Lopez, individually and as class representative, filed the instant civil
27 rights action on March 27, 2007.  On June 21, 2007, Plaintiffs Marsial Lopez, Sandra Chavez
28 and Theodore Medina, individually and as class representatives, filed a First Amended
1

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB     Document 92      Filed 04/01/2009     Page 2 of 9
1 Complaint (โFACโ) against Kern County, the Kern County Sheriffโs Office, Sheriff Donny
2 Youngblood (individually and in his official capacity) and Former Sheriff Mack Wimbish
3 (individually).  The action concerns the manner in which prisoners are searched in Kern Countyโs
4 jails and alleges violations of the Fourth, Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments, as well as
5 violations of the California Constitution.
6 On June 17, 2008, Plaintiffs filed a motion for class certification, seeking certification of
7 two classes- the Post-Release Class and the Group Strip Search Class.  Defendants opposed the
8 motion on July 17, 2008.  Plaintiffs filed their reply on July 28, 2008, along with a motion to
9 strike the declaration of Ian Silva in support of Defendantsโ opposition.  Defendantsโ opposed the
10 motion to strike on October 3, 2008. 
11 FACTUAL BACKGROUND
12 The FAC sets forth the claims of the class representatives as follows:
13 1. Plaintiff Marsial Lopez: After surrendering himself to out-of-state officers, Lopez
was incarcerated in Kern County Jails from June 2005 through November 2006. 
14 When he was transferred between jail facilities and when he was returned to jail
from court, he was subjected to intrusive strip/visual body cavity (โvbcโ) searches,
15 in the presence of others not necessary for the searches, without privacy and in
unsanitary conditions.  On November 6, 2006, he was taken to court and all
16 charges against him were dismissed based on DNA evidence.  He was ordered
released, though when he returned to jail for the sole purpose of processing his
17 release, he was subject to an illegal an intrusive strip/vbc search, in unsanitary
conditions, without privacy and without reasonable suspicion that he possessed
18 contraband or weapons.  
19 2. Plaintiff Sandra Chavez: On February 17, 2007, Chavez was arrested and upon
her arrival at the jail, Kern County Sheriffโs Department (โKCSDโ) personnel
20 subjected her to an intrusive strip/vbc search.  She was searched in a room with
four or five other women and male officer within view.  At the time of the search,
21 KCSD had no probable cause or reasonable suspicion that Chavez or the other
prisoners were in possession of contraband.  She was eventually released from
22 custody and given a fine and probation.
23 3. Plaintiff Theodore Medina: On June 7, 2006, Medina was arrested by KCSD
personnel and transported to jail.  Upon arrival, he was subjected to an intrusive
24 strip and vbc search in a room with four or five other arrestees.  At the time of the
search, KCSD had no probable cause or reasonable suspicion that Medina or the
25 other arrestees were in possession of contraband.
26 Within two years from the filing of the FAC, Medina was also arrested on
a charge of spousal abuse.  While being booked, KCSD personnel subjected him
27 to an intrusive strip and visual body cavity search (โvbcโ), in the presence of
others not involved in the search and in unsanitary conditions.  He was eventually
28 ordered released, and as a routine part of out-processing, he was subjected to an
2

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB     Document 92      Filed 04/01/2009     Page 3 of 9
1 intrusive strip search, in the presence of others not involved and in unsanitary
conditions, in the absence of probable cause.
2
Plaintiffs allege that the searches were conducted pursuant to Defendantsโ policy and
3
practice to indiscriminately search all, or a large number of, persons being processed into jail
4
without regard to the nature of their offense, whether they are under an order of release, whether
5
there was probable cause, etc.  They further allege that Defendants have a policy of not limiting
6
the persons who can see, hear or observe the searches, meaning that other inmates, members of
7
the opposite sex, disposable jail personnel and others are able to see the searches and the class
8
membersโ naked bodies. 
9
Based on these allegations, Plaintiffs allege (1) violation of 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 (Fourth
10
Amendment protection against unreasonable search and seizures); (2) violation of Equal
11
Protection; (3) violation of California Constitution, Article I, sections 7 and 13; (4) violation of
12
California Civil Code section 52.1(b) (civil action for protection of rights); (5) violation of
13
statutory duties, Penal Code section 4030 (policies and practices for strip and body cavity
14
searches)1; and (6) violation of mandatory duties to protect against specific injuries under
15
California Government Code section 815.6.
16
Plaintiffs seek injunctive relief, as well as general, special, statutory and punitive
17
damages.  
18
DISCUSSION
19
I. MOTION FOR CLASS CERTIFICATION
20
Plaintiffs seek to certify the following classes:
21
Post-Release Class (Medina and Lopez): persons who, from March 27, 2005, up to
22 October 1, 2007,2 or the time of judgment or settlement of the case: (a) were in KCSD
custody; (b) were taken from jail to court; (c) became entitled to release after going to
23 court; and (d) were strip and/or vbc searched before release pursuant to KCSDโs blanket
policy, practice and/or custom to strip/vbc search all court returns, including those
24 entitled to release. 
25
26
1 Although section 4030 specifically states that it is applicable only to โprearraignment detainees arrested
for infraction or misdemeanor offenses,โ Plaintiffs believe that the section applies to felony arrestees, as well. 
27
Defendants dispute this point.
28
2 Plaintiffs contend that the policies at issue were in effect until October 2007.
3

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB     Document 92      Filed 04/01/2009     Page 4 of 9
1 Group Strip Search Class (Lopez, Chavez and Sanchez):  persons who, from March 27,
2005, up to October 1, 2007, or the time of judgment or settlement of the case: (a) were in
2 KCSD custody; (b) were subjected to a strip and/or vbc search in a group with other
inmates also being strip/vbc searched, which search did not afford privacy from others;
3 and (c) whose strip searches were conducted pursuant to KCSDโs blanket policy, practice
and/or custom to regularly conduct strip/vbc searches in a group setting.  
4
To qualify for class certification, Plaintiffs must satisfy all of the requirements of Rule
5
23(a) of the Rules of Civil Procedure and any one of the requirements of Rule 23(b).  Rule 23(a)
6
requires (1) impracticability of joinder due to numerosity; (2) commonality of questions of law or
7
fact; (3) typicality of claims; and (4) adequacy of representation. 
8
The burden is on the party seeking to maintain the class action.  In this case, Plaintiff
9
must establish a prima facie showing of each of the elements of Rule 23(a) prerequisites and the
10
appropriate 23(b) ground for a class action.  Taylor v. Safeway Stores, Inc., 524 F.2d 263, 270
11
(10th Cir. 1975), overruled on other grounds by Ruckelshaus v. Sierra Club, 463 U.S. 680
12
(1983).  The burden, however, is slight.  Plaintiff need only present sufficient proof to allow the
13
court to come to a โreasonable judgmentโ on each requirement.  Blackie v. Barrack, 524 F.2d
14
891, 901 (9th Cir. 1975), cert. denied, 429 U.S. 816 (1976).  
15
A. 23(a) Requirements
16
1. Numerosity
17
The class must be so numerous that joinder of all members individually is
18
โimpracticable.โ  Fed.R.Civ.P. 23(a)(1).  No specific numerical threshold is required; each case
19
must be examined.  General Tel.C. v. E.E.O.C., 446 U.S. 318, 330, 100 S.Ct. 1698 (1980). 
20
Generally, 40 or more members will satisfy the numerosity requirement.  Consolidated Rail
21
Corp. v. Town of Hyde Park, 47 F.3d 473, 483 (2nd Cir. 1995).
22
To establish numerosity, Plaintiffs point to the sheer number of individuals who are
23
processed, transported and returned under the authority of the KCSD.  For example, there is an
24
average daily population of 2,500 inmates, and 40,000 new arrests are received a year.  Assuming
25
that the practice ceased as of October 2007, and given the class period of 30 months, Plaintiffs
26
calculate that approximately 100,000 individuals were processed.  Sgt. Gonzales, the
27
classification supervisor, calculated that in 2006 alone, 51,882 inmates were transported to and
28
4

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB     Document 92      Filed 04/01/2009     Page 5 of 9
1 from court and 44,797 inmates were released by the jails.  Declaration of Barrett S. Litt (โLitt
2 Dec.โ), Ex. 9.  Plaintiffs have not yet identified a precise number because they have not received
3 Sgt. Gonzalesโ computer database.  
4 Defendants do not dispute numerosity.  In any event, the numbers provided by Plaintiffs
5 satisfy the numerosity requirement.
6 2. Commonality
7 There must be questions of law or fact common to the class.  Fed.R.Civ.P. 23(a)(2).  A
8 โcommon nucleus of operative factsโ is usually enough to satisfy the commonality requirement. 
9 Rosario v. Livaditis, 963 F.2d 1013, 1017-18 (7th Cir. 1992).
10 Plaintiffs contend, and the Court agrees, that class certification in this action would not
11 turn on the individual circumstances of each search.  Rather, common issues exist where there is
12 a blanket policy of (1) conducting strip/vbc searches of those returning from court and entitled to
13 release; and (2) conducting strip/vbc searches in groups where inmates could view each other. 
14 These blanket policies obviate the need to conduct individualized liability determinations.
15 Defendants take issue with the class definitions, arguing that individuals who were not
16 searched would be allowed into the class.  However, each definition clearly states that the class
17 includes, among other things, individuals who โwere strip and/or vbc searched before releaseโ
18 and those who โwere subjected to a strip and/or vbc search in a group with other inmates also
19 being strip/vbc searched, which search did not afford privacy from others.โ  A basic requirement
20 of each class is the necessity of the individual to have been actually searched.  The Court
21 therefore finds no problem with the definitions.
22 3. Typicality
23 Rule 23(a)(3) requires that โthe claims or defenses of the representative parties [be]
24  typical of the claims or defenses of the class.โ  In General Tele. Co. of the Southwest v. Falcon,
25 457 U.S. 147, 102 S.Ct. 2364 (1982), the Court noted โ[t]he commonality  and typicality
26 requirements of Rule 23(a) tend to merge.โ  457 U.S. at 157 n. 13, 102 S.Ct. 2364.  A named
27 plaintiffsโ claim is โtypicalโ under Rule 23 if it arises โfrom the same event or practice or course
28 of conduct that gives rise to the claims of the other class members and his or her claims are based
5

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB     Document 92      Filed 04/01/2009     Page 6 of 9
1 on the same legal theory.โ  Ballard v. Equifax Check Services, 186 F.R.D. 589, 595 (E.D.Cal.
2 1999). 
3 The typicality requirement is satisfied for the same reasons Plaintiffs have demonstrated
4 commonality.  The Plaintiffsโ allegations arise from the same practice or course of conduct of
5 Defendants, and certainly, their claims are based on the same legal theory.
6 4. Adequacy of Representation
7 The person representing the class must be able โfairly and adequately to protect the
8 interestsโ of all members in the class.  Fed.R.Civ.P. 23(a)(4).  The representation is โadequateโ if
9 the attorney representing the class is qualified and competent and the class representatives are not
10 disqualified by interests antagonistic to the remainder of the class.  Lerwill v. Inflight Motion
11 Pictures, Inc., 582 F.2d 597, 512 (9th Cir. 1978).
12 Although Defendants suggest that Plaintiffs do not fall into the categories they propose to
13 represent, the interests of the class members are aligned because they were all subject to the same
14 blanket policy.  
15 As to Class Counsel, there does not appear to be any dispute as to the qualifications of
16 either Mr. Litt or Mr. Ester.
17 B. 23(b) Requirements
18 Although Plaintiffs seek certification under all three sections of Rule 23(b), they do not
19 address 23(b)(2).  As discussed below, the Court finds the class suitable for certification under
20 23(b)(3) and will therefore not analyze 23(b)(1).
21 Rule 23(b)(3) provides for certification when:
22 (3) the court finds that the questions of law or fact common to the members of the class 
predominate over any questions affecting only individual members, and that a class action
23 is superior to other available methods for the fair and efficient adjudication of the
controversy. The matters pertinent to the findings include: (A) the interest of members of
24 the class in individually controlling the prosecution or defense of separate actions; (B) the
extent and nature of any litigation concerning the controversy already commenced by or
25 against members of the class; (C) the desirability or undesirability of concentrating the
litigation of the claims in the particular forum; (D) the difficulties likely to be
26 encountered in the management of a class action.
27 The satisfaction of the typicality requirement of Rule 23(a) goes a long way towards
28
6

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB     Document 92      Filed 04/01/2009     Page 7 of 9
1 satisfying the Rule 23(b)(3) requirement of commonality.  Gen. Tel. Co. of the Southwest v.
2 Falcon, 457 U.S. 147, 157 n. 13 (1982). 
3 It appears that only commonality/predominance and management are at issue.  As to
4 commonality, the Court again finds because this action involves a challenge to Defendantsโ
5 blanket strip/vbc search policy, the question of law and fact common to the class members
6 predominate over any questions affecting only individual members.  Plaintiffs identify two key
7 questions common to all members: (1) whether the County has a particular strip search policy;
8 and (2) whether the policy violates the constitution.  In other words, proof of liability will not
9 vary among members of the class.
10 Insofar as Defendants rely on the โvastly differentโ experience of each Plaintiff to defeat
11 predominance, they unpersuasively attempt to turn the Courtโs attention away from the actual
12 issue- the constitutionality of the blanket strip/vbc search policy.  In fact, a majority of
13 Defendantsโ opposition and supporting declarations focus mainly on factual issues in an attempt
14 to justify their policy.  Such inquiries are not relevant at the class certification stage.  In any
15 event, the individualized experiences Defendants point to, such as whether Plaintiffs were
16 consistently subject to searches and the circumstances under which each Plaintiff was transported
17 to and from court, have little relevance to the constitutionality of the blanket policy.  
18 Defendantsโ reliance on Klein v. DuPage County, 119 F.R.D. 29, 31 (N.D.Ill. 1988), is
19 also misplaced.  Klein involved a group of inmates who alleged that routine strip and cavity
20 searches before and after court appearances and visitation violated the Fourth Amendment. 
21 There, the court denied class certification, explaining:
22 Here, where there are special institutional security concerns and where each plaintiff may
have been arrested for different reasons, may have had full or no contact with those
23 outside the prison, may pose little or great threats to prison safety, and may have been
searched in a variety of ways at numerous different times, it is questionable that there is a
24 narrow issue suitable for one constitutional determination in the context of a class action.
25 The court also explained that whether the searches were reasonable or unconstitutional โis
26 a fact-specific inquiry that depends upon the way each plaintiff was searched and the security
27 risks presented by each plaintiff.โ  Klein, 119 F.R.D at 30.  Here, however, such issues are not
28 relevant.  There is no dispute that the Kern County Jail has โspecial institutional security
7

Case 1:07-cv-00474-DLB     Document 92      Filed 04/01/2009     Page 8 of 9
1 concerns,โ nor is there any issue as to why each Plaintiff was arrested.  Moreover, while the
2 prisoners in Klein may have been searched โin a variety of ways at numerous different times,โ
3 the variability of Plaintiffsโ searches is not relevant to the central issue- whether the blanket
4 policy, to which all Plaintiffs were subject, was constitutional.  In fact, Klein noted that
5 certification may be proper in cases involving the โnarrow questionโ of whether a โblanket
6 policyโ was constitutional.  Klein, 119 F.RD. at 30.  Put simply, Klein denied class certification
7 for reasons that are either not disputed here, or are not relevant to the ultimate issue.3  See also
8 Blihovde v. St. Croix County, 219 F.R.D 607, 621 (W.D. Wis. 2003) (distinguishing Klein
9 because plaintiffs did not allege that they were searched in accordance with a uniform policy).  
10 While the Court finds that commonality exists, it recognizes Defendantsโ concern over
11 individualized damages.  Individual damage issues do not defeat a finding that common
12 questions of law or fact predominate, though it may warrant a method for handling damages. 
13 Based on Plaintiffsโ representations in their briefing and discussions at oral argument, the Court
14 is satisfied that any individualized damage issues can be properly managed.  The Court can re-
15 visit this issue if and when it becomes necessary.
16 Accordingly, based on the above analysis, the Court GRANTS Plaintiffsโ motion for class
17 certification and CERTIFIES the following classes under Rule 23(b)(3):
18 Post-Release Class: Persons who, from March 27, 2005, up to October 1, 2007,4 or the
time of judgment or settlement of the case: (a) were in KCSD custody; (b) were taken
19 from jail to court; (c) became entitled to release after going to court; and (d) were strip
and/or vbc searched before release pursuant to KCSDโs blanket policy, practice and/or
20 custom to strip/vbc search all court returns, including those entitled to release. 
21 Group Strip Search Class: Persons who, from March 27, 2005, up to October 1, 2007, or
the time of judgment or settlement of the case: (a) were in KCSD custody; (b) were
22 subjected to a strip and/or vbc search in a group with other inmates also being strip/vbc
